  282. Great. Just as expected: simple, clean, adjustable, european plug adaptor without problems.<br /><br />And almost half a price than here (Portugal)
  283. Three problems, two of them major. Minor: It's pretty darn big. Major: The adjustable guide (or comb) is comprised of an upper part and lower part which are perpendicular to each other. Where they would naturally meet and form a right angle, someone (who obviously has never used a beard trimmer on themselves) decided those two parts did NOT need to connect. So there is a top comb which digs right into your skin like little knives as you use the device! IT'S HORRIBLE and causes irregular trimming. Secondly, the design of the blades and the large vacuum port is such that when you're trying to trim the line of your mustache, beard, or sideburns, you cannot SEE where the blades are touching your face/beard, so you can't tell where to trim! And once you do, the blades just barely cut anything at all. It is a useless device obviously designed by people who don't use beard trimmers and I returned mine immediately. I cannot imagine why anyone would like this.
  284. I have read before that beard groomers which feature a vacuum are nothing more than a gimmick. They advertise themselves to eliminate those short, or long (depending on your beard), hairs that are the byproduct of any beard maintenance. The latter is directed towards those men who use manual means (beard scissors), or an electric trimmer without a vacuum. As far as this particular product is concerned: Philips Norelco Qt4070, I will be letting you know how it performs.<br /><br />APPEARANCE<br /><br />What we have first in appearance is a very modern, sleek looking accessory that has a blue digital readout. This is no old fashioned trimmer. Something that the girlfriend, or wife, would not complain (always a plus) about being in view for all to see. So yes, it looks good. Now that we got that out of the way lets get down to actually using it.<br /><br />Before you begin trimming, the manual notes that in order to perform the best job it is best to comb the beard out. But it does not come with a comb (my Remington did). This trimmer is certainly not one of the more inexpensive ones so why not have this included? Moreover, I can attest that combing the beard out definitely does help with a smoother, even trim. If you buy this product I would suggest buying one if you do not already have one.<br /><br />TRIM<br /><br />In order to determine the length that the trimmer will cut your hair, there is a MM and an inch chart on either side that will let you know what setting (i.e. 1 or 2 or 3 etc.) equals what. Personally I never get that involved with exact measurements when sculpting facial hair, but for the facial enthusiasts your need for preciseness will be satiated.<br /><br />After I was finished doing the trim I came to two conclusions about this product: 1. It is impossible to trim under your nose and 2. The trimmings have to go somewhere, and seeing where they go, at least, might be better than not seeing. In the past I have not had any problems with other products in regards to the former, but the Qt4070 would not allow me to get anywhere on the upper lip.<br /><br />There was still some mild shavings that found its way in my sink. It was not a couple, but it was not a lot either. It was enough to leave me thinking that the vacuum did indeed miss a few.<br /><br />If this was the only problem I would concede to the vacuum and agree that it does improve the shaving experience. However there is one little thing that is neglected to be mentioned in the advertising that I was not aware of. As you may know, there is a vacuum that sucks up the hair and while it does not get every little hair, it does get the majority of it. Where does it go though?<br /><br />Does it go in a little baggy that you can empty? No.<br /><br />Does it go in a compartment that you can empty? Sort of.<br /><br />Picture a bagless vacuum. Picture the compartment where all the hair and dust goes and forms that little puffy mass. Now imagine that after emptying the puffy mass, that you would now have to take the vacuum cleaner apart and clean every moving part within it because parts of that puffy mass had coated everything inside. Sound fun? It isn't.<br /><br />That is the experience with this vacuum groomer. After popping open the compartment, there is a wadded little mass of beard hair that simply falls out. Simple enough and quite fun actually. Though now you have to take off the measuring head to brush it and everything underneath. Ok well that is not so bad, right? But wait there's more. You then have to slide up the little razors themselves to find hairs wedged in a not so neat compartment that was not meant to house little hairs. You will then find hairs all under and over the little mechanism that causes the blades to work in the first place (not the razors themselves--the part that moves them). Not to mention you cannot get all of the hairs out. This leads me to think that maybe this will lead to premature failure. This is all described in implicit black and white prints under the section \\"Cleaning\\". Moreover, did I mention that the cleaning section has 17 steps? Yes, 17. And now we have reached why I have given it three stars.<br /><br />This product looks goods, trims good (except for the upper lip), but I spent a good 10 minutes cleaning this after I was finished. Compare this to my non vacuum beard trimmer that leaves tons of hairs all over the sink. However, with the latter it only takes some water and a few hand splashes to get them to disappear. Time taken: 2 minutes and out the door. The vacuum is advertised to eliminate, or at least alleviate, cleaning just enough so that beard trimming can be spotless and trouble free (what else would it be good for?). Ironically, it causes more effort through the extra cleaning. Though the vacuum does work fair enough, it leaves much more to be done on my part which leads me to think it just might be a gimmick after all.cleaning section has 17 steps? Yes, 17. And now we have reached why I have given it three stars. This product looks goods, trims good (except for the upper lip), but I spent a good 10 minutes cleaning this after I was finished. Compare this to my non vacuum beard trimmer that leaves tons of hairs all over the sink. However, with the latter it only takes some water and a few hand splashes to get them to disappear. Time taken: 2 minutes and out the door. The vacuum is advertised to eliminate, or at least alleviate, cleaning just enough so that beard trimming can be spotless and trouble free (what else would it be good for?). Ironically, it causes more effort through the extra cleaning. Though the vacuum does work fair enough, it leaves much more to be done on my part which leads me to think it just might be a gimmick after all.

  293. I had lost my old trimmer on a recent trip, so I replaced it with the QT4070. This trimmer has done everything I need. Numerous beard guard adjustment levels from long beard to stubble. The batter is rechargeable with a plug-in charger. I have not yet had to recharge after 3 months. The only nitpicky thing I would find needs improving is that it would be nice if it included a stand. It doesn't stand on its own, and it takes up counter space when laying flat. If you need a good beard trimmer, I would recommend this one.
  294. So you have a date, and you need to trim that wild mountain man beard down to something that looks more civilized? Look no further. This is capable of cutting your beard with plenty of horsepower left for that mildly troublesome chest hair that threatens to escape through that shirt collar and strangle nearby wildlife. It has a good thick cutting blade like the classic cordless trimmers of years past, not some wimpy easy-to-break foil like certain other Philips Norelco products. The difference is immense for those coarse, manly hairs - it almost seems like other products may have only been tested on baby peach fuzz. Turn the vacuum off when cutting long beards down to size, because the chamber isn't big enough for that sort of operation. Go forth and impress that date with your neatly groomed appearance.<br /><br />A week later, you have another date? Great! Unsurprising, because surely you have a personality to match that marvelous appearance! Time to maintain that beard. Turn the vacuum on and be amazed at how it collects so much of the trimmed ends. There is no such thing as perfection though, so you'll still have to clean some clippings off the rocks by the majestic mountain river you undoubtedly bathe in.<br /><br />Fast forward a couple months later and you've been using it so much that the battery wore out, and (no doubt thanks to your dashing good looks) you have been chosen to deliver the opening speech at a last-minute high society affair - no problem, it operates while plugged into any 5-star establishment's standard AC outlet, so you can use it anytime.<br /><br />Truly, a life-transforming experience. I would buy two and dual-wield them, if I thought I had the coordination.<br /><br />Seriously though, I've used other trimmers that are no longer available which had better vacuum suction, but since those are no longer available, just buy this one and wipe the sink.

  302. If, like me, you go for the \\"5 o'clock shadow\\" look, the T-980 and the QT4070 are very similar - in fact the cutting heads are interchangeable between the two models, and I get the exactly the same results from both. The QT4070 has the fancy digital display, the travel lock, and is somewhat more compact than the T-980, but if you don't care much about those things then you'll get the same shave from the T-980 for much less money. The two trimmers have slightly different beard combs, but I never use them so I can't comment on their differences. The vaccuum feature works about the same on both trimmers, catching most (but not all) short hairs. If you are trimming a longer beard, or body hair, be aware that the longer trimmings can get jammed up in a wad at the top of the suction slot and get in the way of the cutters, so you need to keep stopping to clean them out. In this case you might be better off with a non-vaccuum model.

  309. I try to maintain a short, stubble look, both on my head and my beard. And this rather expensive option has turned out to be the most flawed of the dozen I have tried.<br /><br />PLUSES: The design is very handsome. It's easy to hold, the digital readout is nice, and the battery charge is certainly up for a lengthy trim job of hair, beard and body. I've had models where the trim-length setting slips during use. They have fixed that issue here. However...<br /><br />MINUS: The plastic guides that run across the scalp, face and body are designed to serve two roles. They direct hair into the row of blades for trimming, and the length at which they are set by the user should provide for an even trim. They fail miserably at the second function. The plastic guides are so flimsy, that with very little pressure, they collapse down, or spread from one another, allowing hair to get much closer to the cutting blades than intended. The result can be as bad as rows of near-baldness in-between hairs of the intended length. I have essentially had to shave my hair back to almost bald with no guard just to avoid looking like a freak.<br /><br />This may work just fine for people with a 3/4\\" beard or longer, but do not attempt to achieve an even, short look with this model. It will be a disaster!

This makes it near impossible to maintain a lower cut height when trimming around any contours - the chin especially.<br /><br />They took some steps forward with this design but the gap in the comb(s) is a real issue for me.   313. OK, I'm not going to rehash all the talk about this model vs others that are similar. This is my first cordless trimmer, so I am downgrading the size and power of the vacuum (my other one died after 10 years, but was a beast that could cut my beard and shave my head). This is good for trimming lightly to keep that groomed look. The vacuum chamber holds about 10 hairs, so it needs to be emptied frequently. But the battery, even on TURBO mode, is outstanding. I also like the integrated guard with digital settings by the millimeter--very precise.<br /><br />Mine came with two guards, unlike some of the reviewers' comments I read, so I found the one that I like and I've stuck with it. I don't think I've even tried the other one yet.<br /><br />It takes me several passes to trim my beard, which I do once a week at most. It's sometimes a little uneven, so I go over it every which direction to get it right. Again, I'm stepping down from a monster clipper that was like a corded roto-tiller, so I'm paying for convenience of cordless--and the battery lasts forever! I think I got three solid full beard trims on full turbo the whole time before it was down below 1/2 battery. I've charged it only once ever, so that's nice.

  323. Bought this and It did the job as expected. But I've had this for 22 months and now battery won't charge. Useless and won't power with the AC plug alone. You'd think for $60 dollars it would last longer. In the trash it goes. No more Norelco's for me.
  324. Had an older version of this product which I've had for years. The thing that amazed me about this model is how much lighter it is, but with more suction on the vacuum. Battery charged quickly, and it comes with two different trimmer guides, and the last model only had one. Very happy with this purchase.
  325. This is hand's down the best beard grooming tool. I have owned many other brands. None of them worked as well. Trust me, I'm a beard guy.
  326. works great, vacuum catches a good bit of hair, and long battery life
  327. This is the third beard trimmer I have owned and, by far, it is the best. While others have mentioned its minor imperfections, and some of them are true, to my knowledge this is the best designed, best working beard trimmer--especially if you are interested in the stubble settings; this one has 18 length settings, and the very short ones work well.<br /><br />What sets this apart from the other beard trimmers I have owned is its accuracy. The trim is uniform. I own another trimmer manufactured by this same company, and it simply doesn't perform as well. Not to mention, the vacuum feature works pretty well. As others have mentioned, it's not perfect; there's still a tiny mess--emphasis on tiny.<br /><br />All in all, I highly recommend this trimmer.
  328. I have previously been using a Norelco T870 but the battery stopped holding a charge so I have had to buy a new trimmer. Although there were 3 reviews here that mentioned the guide being faulty I decided to try the trimmer due to the 20+ positive reviews and the lack of a decent alternative. The trimmer arrived this evening so after charging it for an hour I tried it out. The guide is adjustable to give a varying length of cut. The lowest setting gives a 2mm cut and the highest 18mm. Unfortunately, the guide is made using flexible prongs which bend a good 3-4mm. This means that if you use a low setting the guide prongs will bend fully to the blade. I found this out by cutting my lip twice in the first minute of use. I also quickly found that due to the flexibility of the guide using a low setting results in a really uneven cut. I keep my beard pretty short (4-5mm) and there's no way I can use this without the blade cutting me and without making my beard look like it's been hacked at by someone with blunt kid scissors. I think it would be a good product for someone with longer beard hair but for me it is completely unusable.
  329. I have had a beard, and thus have had beard trimmers, for almost 30 years, so I have some pretty strong ideas about what a trimmer should and should not do. IT SHOULD NOT STAB YOU IN THE FACE! But that is exactly what the new QT4070/41 does. For years I was wonderfully happy with Norelco's previous top-of-the-line model, the T980. I love the vacuum feature, the turbo setting cut my tough beard with gusto, and the length adjustment was generally adequate (though the settings were a bit wide apart, so 3 was too long and 2 was too short). But the engineers at Norelco have taken a wonderfully designed T980 trimmer and screwed it up royally. The problem is with the guide comb. On the older T980, the guide comb completely covered the cutting head. But on the new Qt4070/41, the guide comb has tines that extend along the top and front of the cutting head, and END IN SHARP POINTS. So the cutting head sits exposed within a cavity between the ends of the two sets of pointy tines. Yeah, sure, that's what I need to drag across my face all bleery-eyed in the morning - pointed sticks! :-( The new guide comb's design is woefully stupid for two reasons: 1) The length to which your hairs are cut will VARY depending on the angle with which you hold the trimmer against your skin. If you hold the upper face of the guide comb flat against your skin, you get a longer cut than if you allow your skin to span the gap between the two set of tines. And frankly, you KNOW you can't hold the trimmer at the same angle all over your face! BOTTOM LINE: AN UNEVEN TRIM! 2) Even if you are trying hard to keep the flat top of the guide comb flush against your face, you eventually have to turn a corner, like at your jaw line. I have used this Qt4070/41 about a dozen times now, and each time I have managed to jab myself with those stupid tines somewhere - in the jawline, in the chin, in the lip, etc. I know it's just a matter of time before I (a) break a tine, or (b) draw blood. BOTTOM LINE: A PAINFUL TRIM My advice: QUICK! Buy a T980 before it is discontinued and all bought up! Maybe Norelco will fix the Qt4070/41 by the time you wear out your T980.
  330. As others have stated, after two months of occasional use, the little plastic tab that keeps the door of the collection bin closed broke off. I have not dropped it or abused it (can this item be abused?). It's a shame because this is a good trimmer otherwise.
  331. Wanted to go the stubble look so I spent hours researching amazon and other sites on the best beard trimmer/shaver. This is the best trimmer in my opinion. Now I have a full set of facial hair that within several days grow quite out of control. This trimmer has done the job many times over. It trims and collects all the hair quite well, charges rapidly, and doesn't nick my sensitive skin. The travel lock is a nice bonus. One note: If you don't clean the blades or comb regularly and are traveling, make sure to pack it in ziplock as loose hair particles will spill all over! I also wish you could use it in the shower. Other than that, I highly recommend the trimmer!
  332. Been using this for about 5 months.<br /><br />Pros: Trims good. Vacuums good. Battery life good.<br />Cons: Difficult to trim up close up under nose.<br /><br />Overall: Overall works as expected. Would be higher rating if design allowed for closer trim under nose.

As far as accuracy goes, the Norelco QT4070 is unbeatable and gives my face the look I want, pretty much everytime. A must have in any mans tool chest.
  334. Works just as advertised, alllows me to keep my goatee evenly and neatly trimmed with a minimum of work.
  335. This is the worst trimmer I've used. What is the point of designing the trimmer teeth lower than the cutter when the ones behind it are higher with no support?? This is the worst design I've every seen in any product. I used it once and returned it since trying to trim it was a hit/miss situation where in some part it completely removed my beard and in some part it cut to what I set it to. I returned it and got the QT4050 which is a much better design that has the front teeth above the cutter. I can't imagine why this was designed this way, but I don't think the moron who designed it tested it to see how it works. QT4050 is much better and cheaper. Too bad I can't give it negative stars, otherwise I would.
  336. The problem is the primary thing it is designed to do, which is trim beard hair, it does a pretty miserable job of. Maybe if you are a daily trimmer and it only has to snip the end off a few hairs it would be OK, but for a person like me that trims their beard and gets a hair cut once a month it is near worthless. I tried using this alone and would spend 15 min or more before deciding &#34;good enough&#34;, now I start with a Wahl corded trimmer to do 90% of the trimming then finish with the Norelco. Having to use a different product first then follow with this is a joke, I should have returned it when I still had the chance.
  337. Although this was my first trimmer, I think having bought other ones makes me somewhat viable as a reviewer. I was in the market for a \\"stubble\\" shaver. Basically, something that would help me achieve that shadowy/5 o'clock look. At first glance, this shaver seems great. It has a vacuum to help clean up, and a whole lot of settings. Great buy, right? Wrong. The vacuum function, although not all bad, is kind of useless, and that is really what this particular model is known for. Okay... so instead of taking a solid minute to clean up after yourself on a non-vacuum model, you take a solid minute to empty the little basket that they give you. Is it worth the twenty dollars extra over their other models? Keep reading to find out. The beard length settings are way too far apart. 2mm seems too small, while 3mm seems too long. However, there's nothing in between, forcing you to just deal with it, I guess. The blades on this one, for some reason, really aggravate my skin. I've cut my upper lip more than once using this thing, and I'm a very careful user. I initially thought this is just the way things worked with these stubble shavers. Having bought other ones which don't nearly aggravate my skin like this one, I now think that it's a design flaw on this particular model. Since I already bought it, and it served it's purpose to some extent, I sort of just dealt with it. Until a month ago, about 5 months after I bought it, it would spontaneously turn on by itself. Okay, not a big deal, just turn it off. Only happened sporadically anyway. Then, for some reason beyond my understanding, it turned on one day and wouldn't turn off. The \\"on\\" button wasn't responding. Shortly thereafter, it just died. Wouldn't turn on at all. I used it once a week at most. There was actually a good three-week period in which I didn't use it at all. But I never dropped it, immersed it in water, over-charged it, or anything of that sort. In fact, I'm quite careful with all of my appliances and this is the first thing that's ever actually \\"died\\" on me without any cause. I'm willing to give Philips the benefit of the doubt and say that this might have been a lemon. Nevertheless, the trimming function on this one is seriously sub-par. They have other models which are far better, and much cheaper. I don't recommend this product. It has reliability issues and to answer my previous question about the vacuum function, it is DEFINITELY not worth the extra money, IMHO. Good luck.
  338. I made the mistake of listening to the positive reviews on this trimmer. Don't believe them. The negative reviews are correct. The guide is defective for all the reasons given in the reviews. I was unable to get as good a trim on my face, where I keep my beard at 4 mm, as with the old 980--it simply didn't cut all the hairs no matter how many times I went over it. But the real trouble was under the chin, where I cut closer. As other reviews state, the guide does not cover the cutter. And as the cutter is near the corner of the shaver, it will go as close to a curved surface as you let it--no guide to help out. Luckily, the blades don't cut skin, or I'd be bleeding all over. And the curve between the jaw and the neck is the real trouble. Keeping the shaver level with the surface is irrelevant--the problem is cutting the hair around a concave surface. And if you lengthen the setting to recess the blades, those flexible pointy little daggers become the problem that more than one reviewer complained about. Now if you like to cut all this down to bare skin, then this shaver is 4 stars for you. But if you like to keep some beard down there, you're in serious trouble with this shaver--there's no getting an even cut on a concave surface. Worse, I got an uneven cut under my chin on a level surface, and I can't begin to guess why--I kept that guide nice and level like a couple of reviewers went on to say as if the rest of us don't know how to trim a beard. The vacuum works much better on this shaver than the 980. And the door is better than the previous tray, which broke on me and required fixing with super glue, as another reviewer also experienced. The digital readout is great for old eyes. You can also shave very close with this trimmer (no guide on the corner), for those that want such a thing. For those like me with sensitive skin, not a plus. Norelco ought to take the 4070 off the market--it is a terrible product and is damaging their reputation. And those folks that write glowing reviews, if they aren't company shills, then they ought to stop and think about what they are encouraging people to buy. Listen to them and buy it if you must, like I did, but you've been warned. A beard trimmer should be easy to use to produce an even cut, even over the concave surfaces and especially the flat and convex surfaces. This one is not. I've been trimming my beard for 35 years. First with scissors, then with a Remington, then Norelcos. The Norelcos have been great, until now. The 980's motor died, not the battery.
  339. Comes with a great charger. Waterproof, works perfectly, great product
  340. This thing is awesome if you want to keep a scruffy look, no matter what length you keep your facial hair at. The dial for length works great and the vacuum to suck up most of what you're shaving off works wonderfully. It has a very decent battery and lasts quite awhile without a charge. I only use it every other day during the work week but even using it every day you can easily get a week out of one charge. Gave it four stars because the door to the vacuum catch stopped closing properly on my device shortly after I got it. I fixed it with some black electrical tape and just tap out the hair in the sink every morning when I'm done so I only have to thoroughly clean it every couple months.
  341. Before buying this trimmer, I was skeptical about the functionality of the vacuum especially after I read the reviews by other users. My experience, however, was quite different. I would recommend this to anyone looking to 'contain' trimmed hair flyaround. The trimmer blades are efficient and I like the part about minimum or no blade maintenance save for brushing it up.
  342. I've only used the QT4070 twice now, but I'm already ready to dub it the best trimmer I've ever used. Other Amazon reviewers seem to feel the same way, AFTER they have Philips Norelco replace the \\"poorly-designed comb\\". For what it's worth, I'm making that claim about this trimmer while using the comb that came with the it; really don't foresee having any problems.<br /><br />Prior to this, I had used two trimmers. Both of those were good with beard-length hair, but extremely inconsistent with stubble and my sideburns. I haven't put the QT4070 through the sideburns test yet, but it has handled everything else I've thrown at it -- 8mm goatee and 4mm stubble everywhere else.<br /><br />The vacuum certainly helps reduce mess, but it won't eliminate it. This was a motivating factor when I decided to buy this trimmer, so I was a little disappointed that it didn't work as advertised. (The instruction booklet mentions \\"No Mess\\" on several occasions.) That being said, it does vastly reduce cleanup.<br /><br />The feature I bought it for -- the vacuum -- didn't meet expectations, but I was so impressed with the trimmer itself that I still think it's deserving of 4 stars.

  350. Very nice trimmer, love the vacuum system in it.
  351. I wanted to like this. I previously had the T870 or T970 as I can't tell for sure as the model # wore off. It had a vacuum. And I used it to actually shave my face as I like to have a slightly stubbled look and to trim my goatee. That said, I figured this new one would have to be a better design, right? Well no. First off the old one I have had a spring loaded slide where the vacuum would suck the whiskers. The spring would allow you to get the razor close to your face. I am not talking about the guide. I take the guide off to shave and touch up the edges of my goatee. Well this new model has a huge vacuum that is not spring loaded that makes it hard to get the actual razor close to your face. This makes it very hard to be precise.<br /><br />NOT TO MENTION, all the bad reviews for them saying it comes with the contour comb which it doesn't. Well you can call and they will send you one. But guess what, they are always on backorder which I am starting to think that they do that so your 45 day try it or money back guarantee expires.<br /><br />I can't imagine them coming up with this prototype and having guys try it who have used early models. I can't believe they wouldn't have raised all the issue I just raised as well as the contour comb issue. I think they figured that the vacuum being better was the main thing and on paper, the way it's designed it is. The only problem is being precise, which is what you want with a beard trimmer goes out the window. I think they approved the design on paper, then realized after the fact that it didn't work so they figured they'd confuse people by not putting in the contour comb, then when your 45 days expires, you get the contour comb and you realize it still doesn't do what you want, but it's too late. Maybe I am wrong on that, but one thing I am right on is this is not near as good as the old model I had at TRIMMING YOUR BEARD. If having a great vacuum is your main concern then this is your trimmer. I just can'tbelieve they could go backwards in design from the T870/T970 to this.<br /><br />Personally I'd rather clean up whiskers from the sink than have my goatee look uneven and not straight.<br /><br />These companies that try to improve but go backwards kill me. I just can't see any man who works there designing these not noticing the problem. Maybe they all don't have beards or goatees. Probably a corporate policy! No beards at the beard trimmer corporation.
  352. First things first, great shaver, maybe the best WHEN you have all the parts.   353. I purchased this as a gift. The recipient said it worked very well and he was pleased with it. Item arrived in good shape and in time for Christmas.
  354. I previously owned the Norelco T980 and loved it. However, after years of use it no longer held a charge for a reasonable amount of time. Because of all of the negative reviews regarding the comb on the QT4070, I decided to go another direction for a replacement. My first replacement for the T980 was the QT4022. I should have paid more attention to the negative reviews. It's very difficult to use the QT4022 at any length other than the shortest setting. Since the comb doesn't wrap completely around the blade, you have to hold the trimmer perfectly level to get an even cut. Since I didn't always want my beard quite that short, it just wasn't working for me. Also, although I didn't think I would, I missed the vacuum from the T980. So, after more research I decided to give the QT4070 a try. I decided that, other than the negative reviews regarding the comb, it seemed to be the most highly reviewed. And, although not the most convenient solution, there at least seemed to be a solution to the comb issue... call and ask for the contour comb. I placed the order and received the QT4070 yesterday. Much to my surprise (and relief) the contour comb was included in the original packaging. It looks like they may have finally figured out their comb issue. So I tried it out yesterday and enjoy it (so far) even more than the T980. Definitely the best beard trimmer that I've ever tried.

  356. The original vacuum trimmer was much better - too bad they keep changing.   357. So my t980 is starting to get a little dull after I have replaced the blade once, so I figured I would upgrade to the newer, \\"better\\" model. Not so much. Packaging: Easy to open and item came with half charge so could try immediately. What's in the box: Trimmer, charger cord, and cleaning brush....NO POUCH OR CASE LIKE T980!!! Using the trimmer: A setting of 6 is like a 4 setting on the T980. Also, you need two hands to change setting as its not exactly accessible with your thumb The system itself is much quieter than the older models which is nice. The system cut pretty well with few split beard hairs. So, I though the reviews that the vacuum doesn't work that well were exaggerated. They are not! I had just as much hair on my hands and on top of the trimmer than in the hair catch. Onto the hair catch, it's awful. It doesn't pop out separate from the trimmer like the T980 where you can knock out the hair from the side of the sink. A little door opens from the trimmer and you have to shake to get the hair to fall out or get the cleaning brush that came with it. What's te point of that? Overall two stars and a returning products. The two stars are for nice cutting, quieter operation, and nice display of length and battery charge. Missing the other three for disastroopus design, awful vacuum feature that doesn't work worth anything, no case, non detachable hair reservoir, and leaving a mess everywhere. My advice, don't buy until they release another model that addresses the above.

  372. Bought this Norelco to replace an old one that was pretty much falling apart. I went through about 4 different trimmers till I landed with this one. I like this unit due to the fact that the guard setting can simply be rotated in, a very cool feature. Battery lasts forever also.
  373. I bought one of Norelco's first vacuum beard trimmers some years ago. It was very noisy, used antiquated NiCad battery technology, the vacuum rubbed the case and strained if you held it the wrong way, the comb clogged easily, the length adjustment changed too easily by accident, was difficult to re-attach to the trimmer, and I was forever dropping the filter screen when tapping the hair compartment clean. The QT4070 is a huge improvement: Congrats to Norelco for finally employing rechargeable battery technology that isnn't obsolete by the time the trimmer leaves the factory. Sleeping wives will appreciate that the vacuum is MUCH quiter and then sound is less harsh. The depth control locks positively through a wider range of adjustment than I think I will ever need. The trimmer is easy to hold and control. No bulbous weird shapes like some other brands, and now the inclusion of a more modern, light-weight and compact switching power supply that accepts 100V-240V means the kit is lighter overall and easy to pack. A locking feature means it won't turn itself on while stuffed into your luggage. I had been using painter's tape to keep my old trimmer from doing that. The bad: Norelco no longer chooses to include a travel pouch. Is that really too much to ask? I can re-use an old one but other travelers may find themselves using a plastic bag to keep whiskers from floating around in their luggage. One of the included combs is essentially useless. The one without the contour following feature has comb prongs that will jab you, and an enormous gap over the cutting blades that will inevitably cause bloodshed. I don't know who would use that or why. I was hoping for some substantial improvement in the trimmer's ability to capture whiskers. It is a bit better than the old one and the QT4070's noisier turbo mode, yet more so. It's great at keeping longer, lighter cut hair from ending up clogging my sink drain but there is still a fair amount of clean-up of little whiskers required after trimming a short beard.
  374. This trimmer is excellent. I had an older Norelco trimmer that was basically the same thing, and I used it for probably 5-6 years, but it was starting to die and pieces were breaking, so I had to replace it. This newer version works very well for adjusting beard height, and the contour comb piece is great. It is very easy to clean, and portable. I definitely would recommend this, especially for the price.<br /><br />Here are my complaints and they are minor, but they are the reason for 4 stars instead: it doesn't have an attachment for getting hard to reach areas, like under your nose. My old razor had one and it was very convenient, and also good for areas around your lips for mustache trimming. The brush that it comes with is also very tiny and hard to grip. I actually threw it out and still use my old Norelco brush because it's much easier to clean with that one.
  375. At last Norelco has re-designed the beard trimmer to solve the problem with the spring pin loaded comb that constantly broke necessitating having to re-buy the entire trimmer. I'm now on my 4th trimmer in almost as many years. The new comb is a solid piece of plastic that does the job and has no parts that can break. They have also improved the vacuum system on the new models. Gone though, is the smaller trim blade unit. Oh well, you can't have everything,
  376. Easy to use and works well. I like their older model better however that's no longer made and this model does the job.

My partner has also ordered one based on how well it worked for me. This is a great product particularly if you're looking for the stubble look. Previous shavers were work to use (multiple runs to get the stubble even) but this one works like a charm. My shaving time is cut by 2/3. Great product.
  378. The vacuum feature works great and so far the trimmer works great as well. I would recommend this to anyone!
  379. Excellent product, does just what is says it does. This is the second Norelco product, used the old model until the battery would not hold a charge. I will but the next model when this one wears out.
  380. So it's been 6 months and the battery is already dead.<br /><br />IMPORTANT NOTE: Never let your electronics go completely dead, electronics with cheaper batteries or with battery monitors (like this one) need a little power to charge, if it's dead so is the rest of the device.<br /><br />I don't have a super thick beard but it just missed hair after hair. You gotta go over the same hairs 4-5 times. The longer the setting the worse it got. The only reason I didn't give this a 1 star was because the vacuum works very well and with very short shaves it's great. Don't buy this if you want a shave over 3mm, it just sucks (if you'll pardon the pun)

  393. The Philips Norelco QT4070/41 Beard Trimmer 7300 is on the top end of their line of trimmers. I hesitated at first but when Amazon offered it at a lower price than I could find on eBay I purchased it. Great deal with fast delivery. I opened the package, which is a challenge in itself, and plugged it in to charge up. While the battery was charging I took a look at the included instructions. Another daunting task because of all it can do. Once it was ready to go I disconnected the charging cord, followed the instructions, put on the Trimming Comb, set the length I wanted to try, and was ready to give it a try. It should be noted that there is a table in the instructions that give you the length in inches for each available setting of 1 to 18, They recommend starting with a higher setting and descending until you reach the desired length. The Trimming Comb is meant to follow the contours of a man's face and it works quite well. The neatest (pun intended) thing about this trimmer is that it comes with a vacuum Hair Collection Chamber. As you cut it sucks in the cut whiskers, which you empty as necessary. It works great! I was very satisfied with the entire experience. The second time I went to use it, which was about one week later, I again was going to use it without the charging cord. However, the battery was so low it would not turn on. I had to plug it in and use it with charging cord attached. That did not present much of a problem because the cord is quite long. I was however, very disappointed with the quality of the battery that was included. I am hoping that if I charge it longer I will get more that one trim when using it cordless. In summary, I am very pleased that I spent the extra money for this model. It is easy to use, makes clean up a breeze, and resulted in a trim that brought many compliments from my friends.
  394. I have been using different types of trimmers for last 8 years, I never shave and trim everyday before work. This is the best I have seen! Really vacuums all the hair, leaves no dirt and I had no problems using it!
  395. This really is a great product. Had previously used it once at a friends house and when I was looking to buy a new trimmer I figured it was a good choice. After using it for 6 weeks I can happily say it was the right choice. The charge has held very well and the product still works just like out of the box. I use this without the guard for trimming my stubble and then with the guard at 8-13mm for trimming my sideburns and hair and it works great for both purposes. Have never been so satisfied with a trimmer before.
  396. So I want to start out by saying this is a Beard Trimmer not a shaver. So don't expect a close shave this isn't what this product is for. Anyways let's begin. The product came nicely packaged easy to open but had to be charged upon trying to turn it on. I also noticed it came with two guards for the trimmer once preinstalled and the other in the box. I use the one that doesn't protrude into your skin and kinda just lets its glide over you. I knoe protrude sounds harsh and it is harsh if you use the other one lightly you will be fine. The vacuum seems to work great. Hairs still fall but not as many as you would expect so the vacuum is worth it in my opinion. The adjustable settings are nice as well 1-18mm I believe. (I only use 1-3mm) You are also able to take off the guard to be able to get even closer. Gives you a sort of 5' o clock shadow I guess but it wont be shaving it down to your skin that's for sure. I bought this basically to trim my beard but I like shaping it up with a hand razor. Once I have my beard to a desired height i guess (2mm usually) I take off the guard and make an outline of where I'm going to be using my razor. Then I lather up and clean up basically. I'm rating this a 5 it does the job fine because it does say &#34;Beard Trimmer&#34; not electronic razor so it does what it's meant to do &#34;Trim&#34;
  397. Currently, this model by Philips and the Remington Touch trimmer are the state-of-the-art beard trimmers on the market. While the jury's still out on the latter, given its very recent release date, the QT4050 & 4070 lines have been out since 2009/10 respectively. I purchased the QT4070 recently and used it on a 4-week beard. The result was arguably the best trim I've ever had, owing to the innovative cutting design (flat head versus slanted, as with other trimmers), the consistency of the cutting, and the efficient motor, providing the torque needed to trim through a wiry undergrowth of facial hair (the turbo button is useful here). The vacuum feature works rather well, so that roughly 85% of the hairs were trapped in the receptacle beneath the cutting blades, obviating the need to use a towel or bowl under the sink to prevent drain clogging. The included brush suffices to clean miscellaneous hairs stuck to the blades (which conveniently require no oiling or other maintenance). Finally, the versatility of the trimmer, allowing up to 18mm of cutting length, puts it miles ahead of most brands on the market at department stores and pharmacies (Wahl, Conair, Braun, etc.). Conversely, Philips did produce a \\"stubble\\" beard trimmer that was woefully under-performing and cumbersome, so this line of trimmers is clearly an improvement. Overall, I'd rate the product a solid 9 out of 10. In future, perhaps a trimmer operating with lower noise emissions would round it out to a perfect score.
  398. I've had Norelco beard trimmers before and they typically are very nice. This one, however, has a hole in the guide which makes it incredibly easy to slip up on the angle you're shaving at and cut your beard as if there's no guide at all. This is a horribly designed product. I realize that \\"I'm not using it correctly\\" but this isn't difficult to prevent incorrect usage. I shouldn't have to read the directions regarding the correct angle of attack in order to prevent over trimming my beard. Find a different trimmer, this one is atrocious.
  399. I didn't actually purchase this product from Amazon, I actually rushed by a local retail outlet even though I had to pay $10 more, since I had a professional engagement and needed grooming in a hurry. I read all the reviews related to the Philips Norelco, the Braun, the Panasonic and the Wahl products, and my final choice was between the Philips Norelco and the Wahl for good solid results.<br /><br />What attracted me to this product was the fact that it seemed more solid and powerful than the Panasonic (the Turbo button does work) and like the Wahl had the one hour charge with the Lithium Ion battery. While like the Panasonic, since it is adjustable without changing combs you don't need all the bits and pieces that may be hard to find as time goes by. It seemed like the best no-fuss solution, without the vibration of the Wahl and yet more powerful than the Braun.<br /><br />What gave me trepidation was the design flaw alluded to in the other reviews (the gap exposing the tines), and I will be calling up on Monday to get my Qt4050 comb. So it was with some nervousness that I approached actually using the product for the first time.<br /><br />The one hour charge was just that, I plugged it in and charged it and the convenient charge level lights showed it was charged, and it was quite powerful without the chord upon use.<br /><br />But my first impression actually trimming my beard (I first watch this helpful video to make sure I got the angle right [...] was so delightful, I felt I had to write this review because the ones written so far seemed to be giving it a bad rap, and if there had been more positive reviews (I can only speak from my experience with my own medium length beard) my choice would have been much easier.<br /><br />Working from the neckline up with the top flat part against my skin with the comb lifting the hair and the cutters in the first line of attack, I got barber shop results in three passes, one with the setting on 18, and one on 16, and one quick fix-it trim with the comb removed (give it a good pull to remove it, slip it on with no force whatsoever when you have the right vertical angle). Without the comb, my moustache was a breeze to trim also.<br /><br />To finish up, without the comb, I trimmed a clear beard borderline down to my neck in reverse position, without once feeling any pulling or discomfort of any kind.<br /><br />The whole operation lasted a maximum of ten minutes and was a lot of fun.d (give it a good pull to remove it, slip it on with no force whatsoever when you have the right vertical angle). Without the comb, my moustache was a breeze to trim also. To finish up, without the comb, I trimmed a clear beard borderline down to my neck in reverse position, without once feeling any pulling or discomfort of any kind.   400. My wife does not like to find hairs all over the bathroom. This trimmer isn't perfect but it SIGNIFICANTLY reduces the mess from a beard trim to the point where its not hard to clean up what is left.<br /><br />I have nothing but positive things to say about this beard trimmer. I previously had the precursor to this product (T980) I believe and in almost all ways this is an improvement. First off the battery. They switched form nicad to lithium and it was quite an improvement. The battery on this thing just goes and goes and goes (which is great). Secondly it hasn't died. My T980 died after about 2 years which is why I bought this trimmer. It just seems like this unit is going to last a little longer. The reason i'm so positive on this uint, however, is that it DOES A GREAT JOB at sucking up the hair from my beard. When I'm done i usually have a few hairs left in the sink i can just wipe down the drain with my hand and then run some water. Its awesome!!!<br /><br />With regards to the previous model:<br />They've added the digital display which is nice although i don't really stray much from the 5mm setting so it serves mostly as looking nice than functional for me. They no longer include a carrying case and the little mustache trimmer isn't included any longer but i never used it so i'm indifferent on the topic.<br /><br />The travel lock works well although it does require the charging cable to unlock so make sure you don't forget it when you travel (a mistake i did once)<br /><br />The Good:<br /> - KEEPS THE MESS TO A MINIMUM<br /> - Great battery life<br /><br />The Bad:<br /> - Phillips no longer includes a carrying case with this model<br /> - The charging cable is required to unlock the unit once it was put into travel lock mode<br /><br />The Ugly:<br />- When you empty out the hair from the chamber it looks kind of ugly i guess.

  408. I usually avoid Philips products like the plague. I have had experience of expensive Philips products failing the quality test too many times, from active speakers through to shavers. I therefore no longer buy Philips products. I received this product free of charge via the vine programme.<br /><br />It comes in a nice box so would look good for a present. The trimmer itself is sleek looking and appears to be of good quality, but too early to tell if it will last the rigours of the guarantee period. It has a digital display that is very useful and tells you when the battery needs recharging/partially charged and fully charged by use of different colours. The display also shows trimmer length. The trimmer itself can be adjusted to one of 18 different lengths, 1mm to 18mm. The head also moves to allow it to follow the contours of your face. The suction system is not perfect but is pretty good. Some hair did fall away but the system sucks up maybe 95% of all the hair that gets trimmed. So overall the product seems to be of reasonable quality and does exactly what it says it does, trims all kinds of hair safely and without too much hair dropping on the floor. Overall its a good product, but its difficult to judge if it is better than a trimmer at half the price.<br /><br />So great product and is recommended.

  413. I began shaving my head in 1996 and since then I have been using many many shavers to do so. Most of them were corded and it was a real production shaving and then cleaning the area afterwards. I also used a number of cordless shavers when I travelled. After my older Philips Norelco died permanently (the NiCad batter would not charge any longer), I purchased this one. What I realized is that not only it is great for taking it with me while traveling, I can (and do!) use it for shaving at home. Prior to getting it, I would shave one every 2 weeks as the process was time consuming. Now, I do it every week as it take about 5 mins total. In addition, I love the feature that is has for locking the power button while traveling. My older one would turn on while being in the travel case and being pressed lightly requiring me to come up with a way to securely cover the power button with something hard. Overall, I am very happy with the new trimmer/shaver and cannot recommend it well enough.

With the contour following comb here are the pros: -Lithium ion batteries are so much better. -The trim height adjustment does not get changed accidentally like it did with the T980. -It gives a great trim (WITH the NON-included contour following comb). Cons: -The vacuum does not work anywhere near as well as it did with the older T980. I cannot use this trimmer if I already have my shirt on because it blows whiskers EVERYWHERE. Perhaps the vacuum does not work as well with the contour following comb. But one must use that comb to keep from gouging oneself and from gouging out hunks of beard. I give this a 2 star because of the following reasons: 1. Norelco is knowingly false advertising the included accessories. 2. Amazon still is advertising incorrectly too. 3. The vacuum does not work well. I think my next trimmer will not be a Norelco. I have used them for years.   436. Pros: The battery life is good - I only have to charge this every couple of weeks using it every other day. The adjustable length is quite nice as well, especially with the digital display. The trimmer is also quite comfortable to use. This trimmer does the job decently well, but several gripes lower the rating.<br /><br />Cons: The vacuum collects some hair, but leaves a lot in the sink (even if you clean out the chamber between trimmings). It's better than a regular trimmer in this regard, but not quite as good as I'd hoped. The closure for the hair collection chamber is poorly designed - a small plastic tab holds it closed and mine broke off after about a month of gentle use. I now hold the door closed with a hair elastic which works okay, but not great. As for cutting quality, I find that I need to go over the same area several times to avoid leaving stray long hairs and the cut is not the cleanest. I suspect sharper blades would help here.<br /><br />Overall: This trimmer does a fine job for the price, but when it fully breaks I'll be looking for other options.

  438. I bought this solely to keep a stubble / 5 o'clock shadow look -- and I was horribly disappointed. The description says it can trim to 1mm with the comb on, and 1/2 mm with the comb removed.   442. I bought this to replace my old Norelco T980 when it gave up after a couple of years. There really isn't a competing product with built-in vacuum from any other manufacture, so I decided to go with the Qt4070 despite mixed reviews, and I'm glad I did. The \\"contour following comb\\" and regular comb were both included in the factory box. I don't think the new type \\"contour following comb\\" is as good as the one on the old T980, but with a bit of attention it works well enough for me to do the job with only a little poking and snagging on my face. I keep my facial hair trimmed to 4 mm (setting # 4, pretty short) and the vacuum clipping storage compartment is large enough to not need emptying until after trimming is complete each time. I always use the \\"turbo\\" setting, and the vacuum catches about 80% to 90% of the trimmings, similar to the old T980, which is all I expected. With the comb removed (as for shaving your throat, neck, etc.) the Qt4070 leaves a little more stubble than the old model, about 1 or 1 and 1/2 day's growth, which is acceptable to me. If you want it closer you'll have to use a razor. I liked the old T980 little better, but for me the new Qt4070 is functionally equivalent.
  443. This does a nice job and vacuum gets 95% or more of the whiskers. The design may be great for the cheeks and chin, it is not so great for under the nose. While it cuts the hair, it digs in and is less comfortable than my previous razor. The offset on the head also makes it less useful for trimming the hair around my ears, etc. I really don't need an LED light to tell me the setting and I would prefer they use standard razor guard settings rather than mm. I'm purchasing this because the battery wore out very quickly on my Remington MB200. Hopefully this one will last longer. In summary, this is fine and it appears the battery will last longer, but having used both, I would prefer my Remington with a good battery.
  444. I grew a beard just so I could use this....totally worth it.
  445. Piece of junk. Worked for a month and now will barely cut a hair on my face. And the trim length comb is very difficult to remove and re-attach.
  446. East to use - great shave!
  447. I just got my trimmer. It still comes with open, face-stabbing combs not with the proper closed ones. Call Phillips, who now seem to be aware of the problem, and they will send you the closed comb. That problem aside the trimmer seems to work well.
  448. There have been a number of reiviews on this, some a bit mixed. In short, Norelco continues to improve on the design of its vac/trim system and this one is the best one I've owned from them - and they are among the best if not the best out there at this mid-level price point.<br /><br />Use: Used to trim head and body where trimming the hair on my head is the most important.<br /><br />1. There were comments on the trimmer's head being a bit difficult to use, catching on your skin et al. As of at least Feb 2012, they now ship the unit with the standard comb and a contour comb. The latter is exactly like previous models going back at least 4+ years. Best of both worlds. The default comb however does work however a bit more difficult than the contour version on harder surfaces - like my head. However, the default comb hasn't any moving parts and will likely be a bit more durable over time as the contour comb eventually looses its spring ability. Bottom line: its pretty easy to make one of the combs work for face, head, body, whatever...<br /><br />2. The vac system is greatly improved. The turbo option does a good job of capturing the hair and more so, lifting hair a bit to do a better and faster job of trimming. Nice.<br /><br />3. They have reduced the overall size of the unit from past systems and it is now a very comfortable size. Better for traveling.<br /><br />4. The setting display and overall LED display is a nice touch.<br /><br />5. The setting wheel is SO MUCH BETTER than previous setting ring design. Thank you to that engineer / designer. In the past it was easy to start trimming at a setting and before you knew it, you were on '1' due to the ring turning in your hand. The wheel design is recessed and doesn't suffer from this. Nice.<br /><br />6. The lowest setting is now much better for the stubble look, be it on your face or head. As someone who wears his hair at a stubble look, this is very welcome.<br /><br />Good design. Good value.
  449. I have given this trimmer a chance for the last 4 months, hoping that I would get the hang of it after a while. I have owned several beard trimmers over the years and this is by far the worst. I have tried both of the guards provided and also various settings when trimming, and the trimmer pulls my hair while trimming. It hurts and is unacceptable. I won't use it anymore.
  450. After losing my T980 on a trip last week, this was the obvious replacement. However, all the earlier reviews gave me pause regarding the guide design.<br /><br />THIS ISSUE HAS BEEN ADDRESSED BY NORELCO - Upon opening the box, you will find not only the shaver, charger, literature, etc. but also the alternate floating guide that so many have lamented is missing. Obviously, that was something I was happy to see but I can also report something else... The stock non-floating guide that comes with this unit does indeed appear like you should be more careful but it actually seems to allow a much better control of actual \\"stubble\\" length than was possible for me before with the floating guide on the T980... that's right, it does a better job of what it was designed for - STUBBLE. I'm quite pleased that the floating guide is NOW INCLUDED but I'm anticipating not using it as often as I thought I would.
  451. I've had this razor for about nine months and it works very well. It holds a charge for a long time, and works well for a stubble look. Have not used for trimming a longer beard.
  452. I have had this for over a month and it works better than the barber's for beard trimming. So many setting options and the battery hasn't needed a recharge since the original charge at least six weeks ago. This will pay for itself in less than six months.<br />I would definitely recommend this trimmer.
  453. The trimmer works as advertised. I have been using it for a couple of months now and I am not in love with it. I tried to use the lock feature while traveling, but either I didn't do it correctly or the unit malfunctioned. I had no battery when I needed it. I charged the battery up completely when I got back, used it once and then a week later the battery was dead again. I have since charged it again and it is keeping a charge as it should.
  454. I've owned two of these in the last 3 years. The battery seems to keep burning out after a while, first not holding a charge but still usable when plugged in, then giving up altogether. The claim is that the vacuum also prevents hairy sinks, and that's just not true either. It helps, certainly, but does not have the strength to catch everything so be aware of that. The different adjustments is a nice addition, although finding that perfect length does take a few times unless you're switching directly from another brand that does the same thing. The tines on the guard do tend to catch a lot if you extend them for trimming a longer beard, especially on the lips.<br /><br />Overall I'd say it's a good product but not meant for longevity.
  455. I've had previous models of this unit and ran them into the ground. They really honed the design this time, great upgrades. Smaller cutter teeth don't pinch and cut skin as easy (not recommended for your privates without the guard). It's more quiet to run, battery lasts longer, and the digital cut height display is nice. Note that with the height display, make sure to always reset down to 1mm each time, it can get confused if it starts mid extension after sitting for a while unused and can display the wrong measurement. Some of the beard trimmings don't always make it into the collection bin, and can bind up in the chute to it, just empty with a shake/tap and it clears up. This is most likely due to cutter lubrication getting in there (you will need to keep it lubricated with a drop here and there to avoid overheating and slow cutter head speeds). Also over time the collection bin door will fail to stay &#34;snapped&#34; closed and you will need to hold it while using. The rest of the performance is amazing so I overlook these small issues. Eyebrows for me are 11mm, and side burns are 14mm.
  456. It's great product but not exactly show in the picture....!
  457. Functions as advertised. Doesn't leave too much of a mess to clean up afterwards due to its vacuum feature. Definitely recommended.
  458. So far its working great and I am very pleased.
  459. The trimmer works fine, the only problem was the small door no longer closes because the bit broke off to close the door. I am hoping I can use the warranty to replace, and will provide updates if possible.

  461. I'd buy something else. It does a good job vacuuming cut hair in, and making it less messy, but it fails to do an even cut on the jawline.   466. The Philips Norelco Qt4070/41 Turbo Vacuum Beard, Stubble and Mustache Trimmer Pro, first of all ... has a really long name. =) Second of all, it was pure serendipity that this product came up for review for me when it did, because my Wahl beard and mustache trimmer had just started to go bad on me, and I was getting ready to buy a new one, and I was considering an all-in-one unit like this one, anyway. Like I said, serendipity.<br /><br />Right away, I will say that the vacuum feature is a gimmick, and it doesn't work that well. If you have over a day's worth of stubble, forget about it. You will end up with hairs on the counter and in the sink, as per usual. The vacuum just isn't that powerful. Also, if you decide to trim a really long beard into a fairly short beard, same problem, the vacuum isn't powerful enough to contain that volume and length of hairs. Even when you are using the trimmer daily to trim basically tiny amounts of hairs, you will still see hairs in the sink, etc. So, it is a gimmick, but so what? How does it actually perform?<br /><br />It performs beautifully! I have a full beard (except for the neck), which I like to keep about 3 millimeters longer than \\"stubble.\\" I have been using this thing for weeks now, and it does a darn good job, and it does it fairly fast, too. I can generally trim an area with only a couple of passes.<br /><br />Now, as for the life of the unit, and when it will start pinching/pulling hairs (even with regular maintenance), I can't say. But I can say that the length dial works, and the blades cut quick and clean, and the unit holds a battery charge fairly well.<br /><br />Not bad.
  467. I bought this because I had an older model for years and thought it was time for a new one.<br />I use it on my head and an occasional beard.<br />The vacuum feature is great and works well. BUT, the door to the vacuum chamber is very poorly made and broke within a month of about twice weekly use. No, I did not drop it or otherwise abuse it. I use a rubber band to hold it shut and some duct tape to reinforce the hinge.<br />As a trimmer it works very well, but you will be using rubber bands and duct tape to hold it together.

  475. I started growing a beard last year. I've never had one before, and I didn't have a clue how to groom it. I used some heavy duty Wahl clippers for a while, and it worked okay, but they are big and bulky. I was considering getting a body trimmer and using that, but I'm glad I didn't. This trimmer works well. It sucks up a lot of the hair, though not all. The adjustments are good, and it does a good job in trimming the beard. I was a little freaked out about other people saying this thing cuts your lip and what not. I haven't had a problem with that. The plastic is a little cheap and flimsy, and it is sharp on the underneath side, but it hasn't caused any problems for me. I'm happy with my purchase and I will probably upgrade to a 5 star review if the battery doesn't die on me in the first year.
  476. I almost steered clear of this product based upon some of the reviews I read below. I am glad I did not. I purchased this beard trimmer because I have sensitive skin and live in the NE. In the winter, it gets so cold and dry here that I constantly nick myself, and electric razors cause me to have ingrown whiskers. Frustrated, I finally decided I would opt for a beard trimmer: something that would keep my beard short enough that I might still have a goatee as opposed to a full beard; yet, something that would preclude nicks and cuts that might cause breakouts. I have found this trimmer to be perfect for those needs. I keep it at the lowest setting and actually remove the guard so as to cut my beard as short as possible. I have sensitive skin, mind you, and not once has the trimmer nicked or cut it. Not even close. In fact, I am so confident of this Norelco that I bet I could have a Bloody Mary for breakfast before using it and still not hurt myself; I really have no idea how the gentleman who wrote the fearful review is going about using the trimmer. When I purchased it, I was more interested in the trimming aspect; I had no interest in the vacuum feature. That said, it works really well and makes no more noise than a typical electric razor. It is easy to clean and quick to charge. I use the trimmer every morning and charge it for one hour every 7 - 10 days. A note on length. Some say that you are left with a 5 o'clock shadow, but I have a very thick beard. At the shortest setting, I would say that my beard looks like it typically did not at 5 pm, but at 6 am the next morning. Just a tad bit longer. I suppose the effect will depend upon how thick your beard is, the color, etc. At work no one even noticed that I had gone from a razor to a trimmer, so it is surely cutting closely. In sum: after more than a month using this trimmer every day, I have had no nicks, no breakouts, and no worries. Oddly, as one reviewer mentioned,your beard does feel different after trimming it each morning. So go on: don't fear the reaper.
  477. We were looking to replace my husband's previous trimmer that had quite working and found this one. It is not quite as good as that one and that s why I gave it a 4 instead of a 5.

  491. I have had several trimmers in the past. I've been using this one for a couple weeks. It came with the contour comb. With this comb you will not be able get the lower stubble settings. The other comb is the one that can achieve the 1mm beard height.<br /><br />Ok, first of all, let's establish a general scope of what 1mm means to a beard. For those of you that can grow a dense, full beard before you finish breakfast and have a dark beard, 1mm may show a cool movie look. If your beard grows at an average pace or you have a light colored beard or grey or less dense, don't expect 1mm to show anything! Sadly, mine was dark brown, but after 50 years, it is best to keep mine a little longer so people can see it without a magnifying glass. Knowing now what I do, I wouldn't bother with a stubble capable trimmer. It doesn't do me any good.<br /><br />I had a Norelco trimmer that had multiple attachments and I liked it very much. I will buy a norelco trimmer again, but I think I'll buy one with multiple attachments. This one cannot shave or trim nostril hairs. The cutting width is too wide for trimming the length above my upper lip.<br /><br />I looked at the reviews before buying, so I knew what I was getting. I'm giving it four stars because it does everything advertised. The battery is good. The height selection is excellent. The LED display for height and battery remaining is excellent. Noise level medium. Easy to handle and maneuver. The vacuum seems to work. The door to the vacuum storage is ok (it's a plastic door with a small hinge, be a little careful and it will last awhile). It will trim your beard, or other areas very close without hurting. It charges reasonably fast.<br /><br />I added it to my hair trimming arsenal. It has one function and it does it well.

  494. Like almost everyone else, my unit did not come with the contour following comb. I called Philips Customer Care (with whom I've always had a pleasant experience) and by just mentioning the model number and the missing attachment, the representative immediately recognized the problem and took down my information to mail me the contour comb.<br /><br />It's unfortunate that you need an extra step to get the advertised product but Philips has a very quick turn around to make sure you are satisfied.<br /><br />The number to call is 800-243-3050.
