  1194. The beard trimmer works great for what it is intended for, trimming up a beard. It doesn't have a very large amount of adjustability, which is fine as long as you aren't trying to do anything crazy with your facial hair. I use it to keep a pretty consistent stubble and to shave down my sideburns. For those two purposes it works amazing! The vacuum feature doesn't get all of the hair, but it does a really good job of getting most of it. The only thing I wish was that when taking off the guard I could get a closer shave occasionally. Even without the guard the closest you can get is a longer stubble.
  1195. Like some other reviewers here, after 3-4 years my Norelco T980 quit holding a charge. The 7300 &#34;feels&#34; a lot more sturdy than the older model. Whereas the T980 rattled and the length setting felt a little unsure (push a little too hard and it would cave a bit), the T980 had a major advantage over this new model - the vacuum was stronger. Norelco appears to have spent so much time firming up the housing of the trimmer and adding a little LCD display (totally unnecessary), but they dropped the ball on the most important part of a VACUUM trimmer. The T980 caught around 95% of the hairs at 2 days to 1 week of growth, but the 7300 only catches about 80%. That may not seem like a big difference, and that's probably why the product pre-testing made Norelco think this trimmer was fine... but when you're in your own bathroom, an additional 15% of 1000 hairs is a lot of stubble to go searching around your granite countertop to clean up. I find myself spending about 3 times as long doing cleanup with the 7300 compared to the T980. The little cleaning brush they ship with it has also gotten a lot worse. They tried to make it more compact but the bristles are too short and firm. They should fire the engineer in charge of the redesign of this trimmer.<br /><br />Update: I revised by star rating from 2 to 1. Last week, the door to the vacuum chamber suddenly fell open while I was shaving. I tried to close it back and it would not stay shut. I examined closely and the cheap little plastic tab on the door had basically worn out/bent in too far. I have treated this thing so nicely. I never dropped it, banged it around, or anything. I can't believe it broke after only 9 months of use after I had the old model for years. I will not be buying another Philips shaving product in the future - I already ordered a Remington vacuum unit for haircuts that I had formerly been pleased with many years ago.
  1196. This works OK but I like my old trimmer better. The vacuum function on this doesn't work that great, my 12 year old Remington MB 70 that this item is replacing has a vac that works much better. I'd say this one gets about 50-60% the hair. I have a medium length beard so if you have a short beard it will probably get more. The battery seem to last though which is good. I use it about once a week and can get a least 5 or 6 shaves before a recharge. I really like that I can use it while its plugged in, I couldn't do that with my old one. There's nothing worse than running out of juice when your half done with your beard and your late for work.<br /><br />Next time I'll get one without the Vac so that I can just rinse it off which you can't do with this one. I'll make a mess but I'm doing that anyways since the vac on this one is so weak.
  1197. On paper this looked great:<br />trimmings vacuum, finely adjustable increments, cordless -- really what more would you want from a trimmer?<br /><br />February of 2012 - 4/5 product rating<br /><br />I was able to trim and fade my beard to give it a sharp, professional look.<br />It was able to pick up at least 80% of the hair trimmings that it cut -- not bad!<br />(you always had to keep it on full power mode, i have no idea why the normal mode exists)<br /><br />When trimming around uneven surfaces like around the mouth, the guard was insufficient to protect your skin. It nipped the edge of my lips a few times.. but it was ok, just like a standard shave cut -- healed in a few hours.<br /><br />The closest trim setting on it (when you take off the guard) is pretty good for a stubble. However I found that my Wahl and Remington trimmers did a closer trim to the skin (without any cuts!)<br /><br />3 months later - product rating 3/5<br /><br />The front flap that keeps the hair trimmings in started failing. It would not stay closed at all which is pretty important given that the vacuum is one of the main differentiators of this product. The design is composed of a plastic door, on a plastic hinge, with a 1mm plastic lip that clicks onto the main housing. A bit of wear later, the door would not stay closed -- so I had to use some tape to keep it closed. Which is not too bad considering that you don't need to open the door to remove trimmings, just hold it upside down and shake it a bit.<br /><br />6 months later -- product rating 2/5<br /><br />The battery started showing wear. What started off as 1 week of use (10+ sessions) with a full charge ended up being two x 5 minute trimming sessions. Just charge after every use I guess, right?<br /><br />8 months later -- product rating 1/5<br /><br />The battery lasts 10 seconds -- so this is now my limited edition CORDED Philips Norelco QT4070 Trimmer<br /><br />Overall Thoughts<br />I require products to last at least 1 year, with an expectation of two years.<br />Perhaps I got a lemon, but considering some of the designs on this I dont think so.<br />Many reviews on this site are probably from use within the first month or two.<br /><br />My recommendation? Stick with Wahl<br /><br />My suggestion to manufacturers? PLEASE produce non-throwaway products<br />ie. replaceable batteries
  1198. A great product for the money.
  1199. I purchased this trimmer from a department about two years ago for trimming my beard about every other day (setting #4) and the occasional man-scaping. The vacuum feature is quite efficient for limiting the amount of hair stubble that ends up on the bathroom counter, especially with the turbo boost on. The battery life is incredible compared to other trimmers that I've had and I only need to charge it about every other week. I've noticed that you need to exercise a little caution with trimming your mustache on lower settings to avoid nicking your lip, but this is easily resolved by adjusting the angle of your cut. My only negative experience was that the catch for the plastic door broke off a few weeks ago and now I must use a rubber band to keep it shut. Looks a bit ridiculous, but it still works fine, so I deducted a star.
  1200. I'm on the second unit, replaced under warranty. The latch that keeps the trimmings compartment closed appears to be so delicate that after moderate use, it will no longer remain closed. Since this is my second one, I have been very cautious with it, yet the result is the same. Such a tremendous waste of resources and poor design on an otherwise great device. I just writhe thinking about how many of these are going to end up in a landfill.
  1201. First of all, Philips Norelco was fantastic. The trimmer I received had a bad battery which did not hold a charge. Philips Norelco immediately sent me a replacement. Great product, I highly recommend it. The vacuum function really eliminates the mess and clean up. Best trimmer I have ever used.
  1202. I bought this product because the one I had at home stopped working. I'd had it for a couple of years. I was looking for the same model, but it was discontinued. I bought this newer model and I love it! I even paid less for the newer model.
  1203. I've owned a few beard trimmers and so far this is the most disappointing. It fails to deliver on everything the description promises. 1) The vacuum \\"sucks\\". It grabs some of the hair but missed most of them which left them in my sink. 2) This doesn't make an even trim. The length varies depending on the angle you hold it. The previous Braun this replaced gave an even trim so this is unacceptable. 3) The turbo boost isn't needed on short hair and if you're buying this to trim, you'll probably never use it. 4) Portable - This is significantly larger than any of the other trimmers I've owned, mostly due to the fancy LCD screen and the vacuum compartment. The one major complaint I have about this is that it kept catching and pulling on hairs which stung. It felt like it was pulling them out completely rather than trimming them.
  1204. This is a great trimmer. It is very easy to use, and the early complaints about the screen pulling the beard hair seem to have been fixed. I had no problem. The trim length is easy to adjust with a dial and the length lights up. The charge level is readily apparent on the front display. The vacuum isn't perfect, but gets about 95% of the hair. The trimmer works very well. I highly recommend this trimmer.
  1205. The table currently displayed at the bottom of the page for this item notes that this model comes with both the stubble comb and the contour following comb included. I received mine today and only the stubble comb was enclosed. Now I have to go through Philips Norelco to get the contour-following comb. Note that since this item could not be returned (as a personal care product) Amazon refunded my money and let me keep the trimmer, which is pretty awesome. However, I've spent over an hour on the phone trying to get the desired contour following comb and my time is precious like yours.
  1206. The unit that I received did NOT have the guard with the spring actuating clear guard that follows the contours of your face. Thus I had a really uneven and all around poor quality shave. I had to get out my T980 to shave again. I did see that others said that I could call Norelco to receive the spring guard, but this was after I dropped it off at the post office.<br /><br />I had higher expectations for this beard trimmer. On that note I did test that the cutter head from this unit does in fact fit and work in my T980. That's actually good news because I haven't been able to find a replacement cutter head in quite some time as all were back ordered.
  1207. I purchased this as a stubble trimmer so I use it without the guard at the minimum setting. Positives: it cuts evenly and quickly. Cons: It heats up pretty fast, when I turn on the vacuum it stops after about 10 sec. and displays an \\"E\\" so I have to use it without that feature. As others have stated there is a large gap between the blades and the housing of the trimmer so it would be easy to cut yourself though fortunately it hasn't happened to me yet.
  1208. I have a moderate to heavy goatee. I've used other \\"shavers\\" to groom in the past but none of them did as good a job as this. It's settings are adjustable and there is little chance they'll be accidentally changed by routine handling. The trimming is very uniform and quick. As for the hair-catching feature being somehow difficult, all I have to say is \\"stop whining\\" and enjoy the purpose of this device which is to crop facial hair.
  1209. Dammit. I specifically bought this trimmer so I could stab and gash my face all over and sue Norelco, but no such luck. Instead, it did the most amazingly fast beard removal, cleaned up my mustache, and barely a hair in the sink. I don't actually have a beard, what I do have is a laziness gene which prevents me from shaving for days at a time. So then what happens is my facial hair is so long that my electric razor can't get through it, and the little trimmer that comes on the razor sort of works, but takes forever to get the beard short enough that I can use the razor. Problem solved! The 4070 trimmer arrived today, an hour later it was fully charged and I was ready to attack my Geico caveman lookalike face. I set the trimmer on the lowest setting (it says it goes to .5mm, but mine only went to 1mm, what's with that! But no matter, as I later took off the trimming comb so I could go deeper). It simply plowed through the beard like it was butter; super smooth, no nicks, no facial stabbings, no drama. Along the way, whole clumps of hair would stick to the shaver blades and I'd have to pull them off to continue. As others have pointed out, the vacuum feature isn't a shop vac so don't expect it to catch everything if you are doing anything more than a daily trim. But it caught pretty much everything I didn't pull off manually, and at the end the sink and surrounding area were hair free (I know this because it's now 3 hours later and I still haven't been yelled at). After the first go around, I took off the removable 'trimming comb', then got what was left of the beard to a sort of rough stubble, ready to attack once more with my trusty razor (although I could have skipped that step and gone straight to razor, but I wanted to see if this trimmer could be a razor replacement. It can't). I also used the trimmer on setting 6 or so to trim my mustache, something I've never really done before with any precision; the 4070 did a super efficient job, and for the first time ever my mustache actually looked neat and I felt I could rejoin society. I don't doubt the design problems others are having, but I didn't experience any of them. I think this is a great product that comes exactly as described, and does exactly as described.
  1210. I like everything about this product except one thing. I bought it because of the combination of features it offers; it has a very wide adjustable range and a hair catching vacuum feature. Plus it comes from a very good company which is reflected in the build quality. But there was one design feature which worried me and tonight I found out it was warranted. The two comb guards that provide height adjustment don't completely cover the clippers. There's a sizable gap in between them which could allow you to shave a bald spot into your facial hair if you were to say, press down a little while trimming to ensure even length. I will be returning the item and buying something else.

The woman informed me that it does not come in fact come with that comb; I complained that the product's page at their web site says that it does and has a picture of the comb pivoting on a hinge. She told me that they're trying to fix the website to correct that, and as a one-time courtesy she'd send me the contour-following comb. I just got off the phone with her--I'll wait until I receive it to ammend this review with my impressions of the product and adjust my rating.   1216. I should begin this with admitting that perhaps my expectations were too high. I have used the same pair of actual hair clippers to trim my beard for years. For some reason, recently my clippers began pulling my facial hair so I looked for a good trimmer. I landed on this Norelco. The trimmer simply does not give even close to the even cut that I receive with my clippers. I cut mine pretty short, I use the 3 or 4 millimeter setting, so with a good even cut it actually makes a great line to frame my face. They have plenty of power, particularly with the &#34;turbo&#34; and they cut through hair great so I assume it must be from the difference in the type of comb to raise the hair. I do love the vacuum feature that provides adequate suction to get the massive majority of the hair. Unfortunately without being able to provide the same cut as my clippers I will be left to using these solely as trimmers for body hair.

  1229. The vacuum feature is a two-edged sword. It works pretty well but causes difficulty when trying to cut areas of your beard closer when you use the trimmer without the adjustable guard. The vacuum feature adds thickness to the area near the trimmer blades and thus makes it harder to get a close cut. A trimmer without the vacuum feature like I've used for years is much easier to use for this purpose.

  1240. I received my QT4070 today. It may be a little premature of me to give this review now but I have had a chance to use it and I think it's great so far.<br /><br />I am confused with some of the reviews that I have read though, particularly those who state that it does not come with the contour trimmer. Perhaps earlier versions didn't come with it but I think they may have changed that since my one certainly did; i.e. I received both trimmer guides in the box. I am embarrassed actually because, prior to it arriving and having read the reviews (particularly the one telling customers to contact Phillips), I visited the Phillips website, opened a customer services chat and requested a contour trimmer guide. The customer rep was fantastic and sent one out to me with no hassle or questions other than to confirm the order. Unfortunately I cannot cancel the order since it's already in transit and I feel like I cheated them now. Oh well, at least it's a spare if the one that came with the trimmer was ever to break.<br /><br />My only two cons for the product:<br />1) wish there was a loop or maybe a stand or something to allow me to hang it. (no big problem, I'll engineer something)<br />2) the naked trimmer (i.e. without either of the guides) is not prominent enough (what I've been used to in the past) to get a good trim for definition making it kind of awkward to use for that. no biggie for me personally because I have a small travel trimmer and my razor that I can use for that.
  1241. The multi-year long-life battery this thing uses is pretty worthless when the clip that keeps the door of the hair trap shut is made of cheap plastic. I called Philips Norelco about having it fixed to keep hair from spilling out all over my counter, and they told me my only option was to buy a new one. Super lame. How are we as consumers supposed to keep waste out of landfills if lazy companies sell us products that never last more than a couple years and can't be repaired?<br /><br />When it worked, I liked the thing alright. The vacuum isn't perfect (it probably gets about 75% of the hair), but for the most part I had no other problems. Just know that you're buying something with a 2-year lifespan.
  1242. I've had a full beard for 30 years and have used Norelcos since the beginning. This QT4070 replaced a Norelco QT4021 which only lasted about a year. The design problem with the latter is that its contour-following comb piece retains the blade; so, when the comb hinge cracked, the blade loosened and disabled the unit. I thought of ordering a part from Norelco, but decided it was a bad design to start with, and that the kind of trim I was getting from that one was not worth the hassle or wait.<br /><br />I am very pleased with the design and the trimming of the QT4070. Unlike some others' experiences/reports, the unit I got from Amazon last month came with both a \\"stubble comb\\" and a \\"contour following comb\\". The stubble comb works fine, but it is not comfortable for my fairly thick 3/4 to 1\\" beard -although the cutter does not reach the face/skin by any means. The cutter or blade is built into the base, so any damage to the combs will not affect the operation of the unit. The removable contour comb is very comfortable, and the trim with the contour comb is as good as I was getting from my old Norelco. The vacuum makes the clean-up easy, although some cuttings do stay on the unit head and a few more tumble out. The only aesthetic flaw is a white strip winding through most of the unit. Black and gray would would have been plenty of coloring and made for a classier looking unit -to my sensibilities, that is; although -to paraphrase Alan Iverson- we're talking about shaving here, men, and we're the only ones who have to look at this thing every every other day or so.
  1243. I believe Norelco has solved the trimmer issue mentioned in the negative reviews. I just purchased the QT4070 and it has both combs included with the trimmer, Trimming Comb and the Contour-following Trimming Comb. It matches the part numbers in the cautionary reviews. The Stubble Trimmer has been discontinued as a replacement part. Hope this helps others looking at the product.

After another month or 2, it literally flaps open whenever I even turn over the unit. The latch that holds the door closed is a tiny piece of plastic that does not seem to be durable at all, and after being used consistently, seems inevitable to break. I would not recommend this product, unless you only plan to have it for a short period of time.   1270. PROS: It works as a beard trimmer. The vacuum is a nice feature. I &#34;taper&#34; my beard, so the distance-from-the-face adjustment is not useful to me. However, you can fully retract the length guide and expose the cutters so that you can have complete control.<br /><br />CONS: It desperately needs a charging stand of some sort. There are no flat surfaces anywhere on this trimmer, so you can't rest it on either end. Shelf space is a premium in my bathroom, and I never had a space big enough to put it down on its side. I finally brought a heavy mug up from the kitchen and use it as a dock. Since there's no stand, managing the cord is also a constant problem. You can't just run it to a plug once and forget about it, you have to do that every time you charge the clipper.
  1271. First, this review is strictly about this product as a stubble trimmer.<br />I have had two stubble trimmers in the past few years.<br />The first was the Philips Norelco QT4021 Stubble Trimmer.<br />I liked it but once it died I discovered a better product.<br />The second was the Conair iStubble.<br />I loved it, until it died. Went very short and was smooth leaving no hairs.<br />Next, I decided to give this handy dandy vacuum one a shot.<br />Yes, it did suck up almost all of my stubble (might not work so well for beards).<br />BUT, it was rough on my face, didn't go very short, and missed a lot of hairs.<br />It also took forever to shave my entire face, neck, and didn't get under my nose well.<br />And the turbo is a joke, just loud. HATE IT.
  1272. The vacuum feature is useless and it's the only reason i bought this one.
  1273. It lost a star because its larger size and loud noise. It doesn't shave as close as the smaller models even without the comb attached and the size makes it harder to get the edges and corners right without hitting their surroundings.
  1274. I have had this for over a year now, and I don't like it. It is not nearly as good as the previous Norelco that I had for many years (that finally completely wore out).<br />1) First, the 0.5mm closest shave is not what I experience -- more like 1.5 to 2 mm on my stubble.<br />2) Second, it was supposed to come with a contour following comb, which was NOT included. I checked with customer service, and it was 'not in stock'.<br />3) Third, after the trimmer was out of the Amazon return period, the sharp tined comb that was sent grabbed a loose piece of my skin and the blade bit my face a tiny bit, drawing blood. Not happy.<br />4) Fourth, the plastic cover that holds the vacuumed hair in it's little chamber broke. The latch that holds the cover closed is a cheap thin plastic extrusion on the cover. Far too thin to last a long time on a latch stress point like this. Seems like very poor engineering on this part, or planned obsolescence, Now I have to hold the door closed with my hand for the vacuum to work.<br /><br />Norelco used to be really good. But this thing was a huge disappointment.
  1275. Great trimmer but the vacuum isn't the best! Still love it tho!<br /><br />Very big improvement from what I was using.
  1276. And, it cuts well. The adjustable feature is great for cutting the beard and mustache and different lengths. The digital display is easy to use. And the vacuum has a low/high speed setting.
  1277. I gave this to my boyfriend for his birthday and he loves it. It keeps the sink nice and tidy and he says that it makes shaving a breeze!
  1278. Even better than I expected. I had been using the Philips Norelco T980 Turbo Vacuum Trimmer since Christmas 2006 and I really loved it! But it finally became sort of worn out. Yet it was difficult to think much real improvement could be made on that great product. I was WRONG! The QT4070 is far superior in almost every way. It is smaller and lighter and thus easier to handle. It is also MUCH easier to clean! It is a dream come true for this type of appliance. I could not be happier!<br /><br />UPDATE 7/4/2013:<br />STILL proud of this purchase! Been using it for 2 months now. Battery lasts MUCH longer than the T980. The cuttings chamber appeared smaller than the T980 yet somehow it isn't so I can usually get through a complete usage without having to empty it. Some background why that is significant. I not only shave my beard but also my entire head--at the 1 mm shortest setting! I hate having to shave but not as much as I hate not shaving. So I shave only every 2 weeks or so. Not only is the chamber big enough, but even the vacuum \\"tunnel\\" (between blades and chamber) remains pretty free as well. So that makes the whole job quicker and easier. But even after shaving my entire head, the battery indicator is still full or near full so I don't usually have to recharge until after at least 2 shaving cycles. THAT IS NICE! And no, I don't work for or own stock in the company. I'm just a happy user.
  1279. These trimmers/clippers have a built in vacuum to save me from having to clean up the bathroom. It also has the strength to even shave my head. (of course my head is maintained fairly short.) I would suggest anyone that likes a good clean trim to purchase this product.
  1280. The battery did not last very long at all on the first charge, but that seems to have been a fluke.   1295. This looks like a very good product, and I'll definitely keep it. It is very easy to use and seems to be well-built (I have been using a Philips shaver for many years and never had a problem with it - this one seems a little bit more fragile because of the LED display, but still looks solid).<br /><br />However, the only reason why I chose this one and not other similar products (some of them cheaper) is because it has a vacuum system that is supposed to catch facial hair, according to the description, &#34;without leaving a mess in the sink&#34;. Well, the system does catch some of the facial hair, but it still leaves some mess. And I suppose this must be much worse for those with extremely dense facial hair who will need to use that &#34;turbo&#34; button most of the time. I hope the system becomes better in future versions - as is, it is definitely not the dream machine being advertised, at least as far as that feature is concerned.

I chose this model because the one thing that always bothered me was the mess of stubble that would collect in and around my sink when shaving/trimming. And, this one could run in both cordless and corded modes. If my old one had a corded mode I would probably still be using it.<br /><br />I'm giving it 4/5 stars because it does a nice job of minimizing the mess; but it doesn't eliminate it.   1304. It does what it is supposed to do but not without a couple hiccups. This is a fine beard trimmer but you have to pay attention to a couple things in order to not accidentally mess up your glorious man beard.<br /><br />We'll start with the good. I enjoy the quick easy adjustability with the turn of a dial because I like to trim the areas directly around my mouth (mustache and soul patch area) closer then the beard itself. The readout is a wonderful idea... and would be much better if it worked correctly. The LED readout tells you the length in MM.<br /><br />The problem is the led readout is quite unreliable, it gets confused oftenly and that has caused me a serious issue on one occasion (No more I'm super careful now) The readout got stuck when I dissasembled the razor to clean the hair out and when I used it the next time I dialed the LED to the number I usually trim at, and when I went to shave it was on a 2!!! My beard was gone. I started noticing that it seems it relies on some sort of contact which if it gets dirty will cause it to go haywire. Even now that I noticed it I will occasionally see the LED number jump around or get stuck on a number I just have to be ultra careful (there is also a Standard measurement hard guide painted on the backside you can use to double check)<br /><br />The other thing I will say is while the vacuumm feature is nice it isn't 100% reliable. The channel it uses to vaccumm the hair gets clogged too easily and is very hard to clean (because you aren't supposed to use water on this).<br /><br />It works well but I have to imagine there is something else better out there, in the meantime this will get the job done.
  1305. I like the idea of the vacuum container, but it certainly was not sufficient when i took off 2 months of beard growth. We'll see how it does with more routine maintenance of facial hair.   1313. Beard never looked better and this thing will hold a charge for a month with full beard trimmings every 3 days. To clean it out I take it outside and give it a quick blow with the leaf blower.
  1314. Used it for the first time and I'm pleased so,far. I will update later. This is my third Norelco and I have been pleased with each trimmer.
  1315. This trimmer has two uses, and excels at both. First, if you want the scruffy look, this is an easy way to get it and keep it. You can set the length of scruff you want (I use 3mm), and then just run this over your facial hair every three days or so. Takes way less time than traditional blade shaving, and you don't have to do it every day.<br /><br />Second, if you have too much length to easily shave with a blade (say, after a long, casual vacation), this trimmer can reduce the length down to something easily manageable with a blade. For that, I go all the way down to 1 mm. It is much faster and easier to do the two-phase approach (trimmer, then blade shave) than to try to make a five-blade razor chop through 1/4 to 1/2 inch facial hair. It's worth having this device for that purpose alone, because it isn't very expensive.<br /><br />In either case, it's easy to use. Just slowly brush it over the area you need trimmed. Some areas I find it helpful to approach from two directions, one after the other. The neck under the chin is an example.<br /><br />You set length by twisting a dial, using finger and thumb. The dial goes through the device, and is exposed on both the front and back. An LED shows the length, and a scaled area on the sign does too. The LED is in millimeters, while the scaled area is in fractions of an inch.<br /><br />A single charge works over a month for me. It recharges fairly fast.<br /><br />One minor glitch: at one point when I was fumbling with the length adjustment, the dial slipped and then the trimmer would only go down to five millimeters. I had to force it all the way in the other direction to make it slip the other way, and then it was fine. Lesson from this is, don't force that dial, and pay attention to what you're doing.
  1316. It's pretty comfortable, lasts a while on a charge and it's my first with the built in vacuum which does a fairly decent job of preventing larger cleanup efforts. If only it could cut the gray hairs lower than the the others.....
  1317. Have used/still use multiple, various razors and trimmers, primarily Norelco and Braun. This recent addition was purchased to simplify the '3-day beard' and 'essentially-bald' effect. So far it has fulfilled its purpose. Will update as necessitated.

  1330. Nice shaver from philips, the vacuum prperty works fine. Battery charge is long enough and over all the unit is of good quality
  1331. After a lot of internet research, I settled on this trimmer. The 18 mm trim length is one of the longest I've seen, and since I recently decided to grow my beard longer, I needed something that gave me more margin for error. The trimmer comes with two combs, the basic stubble comb and the contour following one. Personally, I prefer the basic stubble comb as the contour one tends to get tangled in my beard. The motor is strong, with no noticeable decline in power when on battery alone. The battery life is good, lasting me multiple shaves (I haven't counted exactly, but I really only trim once a week, so I imagine I could easily go over a month without charging). My only complaint is that, as others have noted, the vacuum component is relatively mediocre. Sure, you'll definitely notice a reduction of hair falling on your sink, but you're still going to have to do some clean up. It's a great trimmer, and I highly recommend it, but I wouldn't treat the vacuum as a deciding factor, it doesn't work that well.
  1332. This razor is awesome. I've been using it daily for months now. If you have long facial hair or move too quickly the trimmer won't collect it all but it's still a huge upgrade from one without it. I highly recommend this bad boy.
  1333. Won't keep a charge. I'll use it for a few minutes in the morning, plug it in to charge it, and it reports full charge. Half a week later when I go to use it again, there's a 50/50 shot that it says the battery is completely empty. I just engaged the travel lock, which is done by holding the power button. While the button is held, the shaver ran, and it reported a full charge. I set it down, and then thought I should test the unlock function. I can't, because by the time I picked it up again, the unit reports a completely empty battery.<br /><br />Fortunately, I can use it as corded, but then why pay for the expensive lithium ion battery? There's only 30 days to return it, which for me was not long enough to discover the battery problem. Do yourself a favor and buy something else.

  1349. The Turbo feature is well worth the extra $10.00. Performs as expectated. Keeps the sink clean and virtually no stuble escapes the vacuum.
  1350. As a man who's been trimming his own beard/hair for the past decade (ladies, if you see a balding man at the hairstylist that man is quote obviously RICH given today's prices for a trim), I've used my share of Norelco (and their competition's) electric razors.<br /><br />Out of the 7 or so that I've used in that time, 6 failed at the battery from continued use. Most tend to suffer from poor design, and when my last razor broke (battery kept getting weaker and weaker), I started hunting for the oh-so-familiar Norelco cordless. Considering I'd already spent about $300 in unreliable razor over the years, I decided to take the leap and try a more expensive (>$40) model.<br /><br />Well, so far this has been the BEST Norelco electric razor that I've owned. It becomes obvious after using so many of these that their product line gets better-engineered above a certain price point. This razor not only has the best ergonomic shape for holding behind your head, but it is lightweight and the integrated vacuuming really keeps trimmings from flying all over the place while you buzz. Apparently this also leads to a better cut from what I've seen so far, as previous razors would discard trimmings onto the head while shaving leading to a 'rough' hairline profile.<br /><br />Just about every 'nearby' model of Norelco will share the same charging system, but be sure to read the exact voltage/current specifications on the adapter to make sure you don't rush the razor to an early death. The Qt4070 comes with 2 combs, and both are difficult to place on the razor's rails - just something you have to get used to. If you trim without the comb, you might find it a little more difficult as there is about a 3mm gap between razor blade and razor body which requires you to tilt the razor up at an angle to get around your ears or trim a moustache. Not much else comes in the box aside from the standard brush and instruction manual in 28 different languages showing how to plug it in and how you shouldn't shave underwater.<br /><br />Oh yeah, the LED charging status and blade level indicator will eventually time out and go dark while the unit remains plugged in, so if you're one of those people who are bugged by stupid-bright LED lights on 100 different appliances at night, this won't be an issue with the Qt4070.<br /><br />Lastly, for those shady resellers who are trying to gouge the electric razor market on Amazon with stupidly overpriced DISCONTINUED Norelco models, you can get lost. Norelco is always releasing better and newer models, which makes your efforts pretty useless.<br /><br />If you're looking for something newer and better, BUY THIS RAZOR.yeah, the LED charging status and blade level indicator will eventually time out and go dark while the unit remains plugged in, so if you're one of those people who are bugged by stupid-bright LED lights on 100 different appliances at night, this won't be an issue with the Qt4070. Lastly, for those shady resellers who are trying to gouge the electric razor market on Amazon with stupidly overpriced DISCONTINUED Norelco models, you can get lost. Norelco is always releasing better and newer models, which makes your efforts pretty useless. If you're looking for something newer and better, BUY THIS RAZOR.
  1351. Good one, easy to use, Vacuum is working good and most of hair got collected. Little bit on higher cost

  1356. I have had many eletrical/elecronic razors before this one.but none of them could be used for a stubble 5 o clock look. Qt4070 came to my rescue.... Has many calibrated levels and gives a smoth and even beard....definitely a must buy!!
  1357. Within about a month the little door that holds your beard trimmings broke. There is a small plastic piece that snaps into the housing of the trimmer to secure the door and that piece broke off. I had used it maybe 4-5 times at that point and hadn't dropped or in any way been rough with it, so it's pretty inexcusable for it to break in that short of a period of time. While the trimmer is still usable, the door can come open on it's own and sprinkle it's contents in a clump in my sink.<br /><br />That being said, here are the high and low points of the trimmer:<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Nice shape and feel<br />-Cool display that shows battery remaining and the length the guard is set to<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Poor build quality (broken door)<br />-Vacuum feature is more of a gimmick. It sucks up maybe 1/2 to 2/3 of the trimmings, the rest falling in to the sink like any other trimmer. If I'm going to have to wash some of the trimmings down the sink anyway, it doesn't really matter if it's 1/2 of them or all of them.<br />-Vacuum feature adds a little plastic channel that pops out under the blades that makes trim/detail work difficult to do. My previous trimmer I would take the guard off and use it do do the bottom edges of my beard and mustache area around my lips. I can't do that with this because the air channel for the vacuum gets in the way. I have to switch to the pop out detail attachment on my electric shave to do this now.<br /><br />This is the second bad experience I've had with a Norelco product and I can guarantee you I won't be having a 3rd bad experience as I'm never buying Norelco again.
  1358. Great trimmer, my husband loves it. Has a vacume to catch extra hair, so I love it. Powerful, holds charge good, plenty of attachments to use with it.
  1359. I had it for a month and a half now, and are very happy with it.It does a good job.
  1360. I do have their previous VACCUM model and have to replace because it is not holding charge. When I got the QT4070 I was disapointed because of the following things:<br /><br />1. Does not have the detailed small trimmer that is very useful for cut hair behind the ear and close to the nose (the small trimmer was available for the older model and works very well)<br /><br />I called NORELCO and they understood my feedback but have been unable to help or to provide a more pricey model that would have those features. Indeed they suggested I tried to buy another old model via ebay or any other site.<br /><br />Not what I was expecting. Weird they are making a device that is worst than previous one.

  1365. Pro:<br /><br />- Corded / Cordless<br />- Long Battery Life<br />- Vacuum Function ( also a Con ) *Easy Clean Up<br /><br />Con:<br /><br />- Vacuum Function *Only sucks up about 50% of the cut hair<br />- Blades do not protrude enough to be used for lining or detail work. Can only cut in upward motion with front/ display side facing the ceiling. because the vacuum portion block the blade any other way.<br />- Only the contour attachment is worth using.<br /><br />Preciously owned a similar shaver/ trimmer to the Philips Norelco G370 http://www.amazon.com/Philips-Norelco-G370-Grooming-System/dp/B000FED5DU/ref=sr_1_1?s=hpc&ie=UTF8&qid=1362518685&sr=1-1&keywords=norelco<br /><br />It worked well but i wanted something that would be able to work cordless/corded and something that would be able to trim and line my beard/ goatee up.<br /><br />I really did love the QT4070 as a trimmer and for its vacuum function. But it really fell short in many ways which is why i had to return this product. You can only use it in the upward motion and it is very hard to line a beard or goatee up since you cant see what your cutting if you can only use it in the upward direction. The vacuum function seemed good but i found that it didn't catch all the hairs and was fairly noisy. I wish that the vacuum function had more sucking power in order to get most is not all the hair that you cut. I would have also liked it if the blades would protrude farther then the vacuum tube. The vacuum scoop is right up against the blade and is just as long so if you try to line or use it in any direction other then having the front/display area facing the ceiling you end up having the vacuum scoop against your skin and the cutting blades are unable to cut any hair.<br /><br />If you have a trimmer you like to use or like to use a razor or straight edge to line your beard or goatee this will be great but there are many other trimmers that will do just as good for half the price and have better cutting accessories.

  1372. Got it after I was looking for a beard trimmer for a while. It's a little pricey (got it as an open box , $42.99) since it's not a multi-trimmer and just a beard trimmer. The battery life is really great, you get 75 mins of charge for 1 or 2 hours of charging. To get into proportions- most trimmers give you 20-30 mins of work for 10 hours of charging. So the rechargable Lithium-Ion battery is worth it.<br /><br />The trimmer itself works pretty well, including the vaccum feature that supposed to keep your sink and house from getting hair all over the place. The only problem was because I had a full beard (grew it for a couple of months) the hair tray got full really fast, so I ended up cleaning it pretty often while trimming. Also, the LED display with the length of the beard works well and is useful.<br /><br />Overall, I would recommend this beard trimmer.
  1373. Talk about nice. Shaving was a breeze and left me with just what I wanted. Vaccuum picked up around 90% of the hair which made cleanup alot easier! Turbo button is nice to have as well. I'm impressed! Should have bought this sooner!
  1374. The unit is much bulkier than my last one. A good trimmer should feel sleek and cool, IMHO.<br /><br />The vacuum didn't catch everything, so a sink cleaning is still needed, although I must admit the clean up is much easier than I'm used to.<br /><br />I plan on returning this and getting a smaller unit.
  1375. I purchased the Philips Norelco Qt4070 Turbo Vacuum Beard, Stubble and Moustach Trimmer Pro, Black/silver. It arrived quickly and undamaged. I got this one to replace the older version that I had for a long time. It works well as advertised. Mine came with the \\"sharper\\" comb as well as the more \\"rounded\\" comb. I prefer and use the more \\"rounded\\" comb which is what my older clipper had. The \\"sharper\\" comb tended to irritate me. If Yours does not come with the More \\"rounded\\" comb, you can contact Norelco and they will send you one free of charge.
  1376. Dear Amazon Shopper,<br /><br />Let's be clear, for the vast majority of you, this trimmer is not likely to be worth $50. This trimmer will not replace your razor. Neither will this trimmer, with any of its accompanying attachments, effectively trim a scraggly beard unless you've been living in a cave without a razor for half a year or more. The only way to get a decent trim out of this thing is to use NO ATTACHMENT AT ALL. I use this in a razor-assisting capacity for when I've gone a little while without shaving and my beard is a bit too long/tough for my normal electric razor. With no attachment, you can actually trim your facial hair to a reasonable level and finish it off with a standard razor. To other reviewers who have said that this product enables them to no longer use a razor, I cannot fathom, logistically, how that could be.<br /><br />For the average shaver, this trimmer strikes me as being good for all of two things:<br /><br />1 - The vacuum feature of this trimmer picks up about 70% of the hair that would normally get all over the sink when using a normal razor/trimmer. This feature SIGNIFICANTLY increases the ease of cleanup, which is this product's saving grace.<br /><br />2 - This product, with no attachment, WILL work to trim your beard down to a level where a once-over with normal razor will leave you with a clean shave.<br /><br />It doesn't come with a stand, so prepare to leave it in a drawer. It's cordless, which is convenient, but I'm rarely far from the sink, so I can't comment on battery life. I consider this a non-issue though, since on its own this trimmer's usefulness is extremely limited (nil in my case), meaning its battery life is at best only as good as that of the product it is functionally tethered to.<br /><br />This offering from Norelco is JUST shy of a swing and a miss. However, if anything I've mentioned makes this product connect in some way with your intended use, it might be worthwhile to pick up if significantly discounted.discounted.
  1377. good at trimming beard down to a specific lenght--vacuum of hair a plus.<br />however, NOT good a trimming EDGE of moustach or beard. need another type trimmer for that as well as for nose and ear trimming<br /><br />not all that i thought it would be but still worth the price since it easily adjusts to a wide variety of lenghts of trim
  1378. Powerful, quick charge,works great<br /><br />Only downside is door to compartment for trimmings appears poorly designed and breakable, will be extra careful.<br /><br />Would recommend to all
  1379. The 0.5mm setting is what I wanted - this does many fancy things, but I wasn't looking for a beard/mo mower. Specifically I wanted the short 5 o'clock shadow look at 9am, this was the only thing that specified that 0.5mm length.<br /><br />Here's my list of things I didn't like - This does an ok job of trimming for 5 o'clock, but isn't that easy to get under the nose or nooks and crannies (as the unit is quite large), so you have to really work it. It may be useful to know that the 0.5mm setting is with all attachments removed. The vacuum is ok, I have black hair which did get on the sink, which meant that there was still clean up to do (nothing like the Philips video btw, which made it look so great).<br /><br />If you are doing beard shaping this trimmer could be your best friend, but for what I was looking for it was overkill on features, and underwhelming on delivering the 5 o'clock look. Time to go back to the mini-Wahl...
  1380. Great trimmer that I use at least 3 times a week for my beard and hair. The battery last for hours and I highly recommend this item to everyone. I promise that you will no be disappointed at all.
  1381. I was so disappointed with this razor. I have a beard that I keep fairly trim. I don't go for the stubble look, but keep it probably around 3mm. My previous razor had finally died and thus I needed a new one. Having always held the bathroom garbage can under my chin to catch the hairs, I thought this vacuum feature would be fantastic. In actuality, hairs still go everywhere and while it does suck in a handsome amount, a lot still ends up on the floor (yes, I tried it without the garbage can under my chin and made a mess). That, however, is not why this razor gets a 1 star. The issue is with how the trim guide is designed. If you look at the pictures closely, you'll notice that the trim guide is set back from the razor blades. This means that if you change the orientation of the razor with your face, then you can accidentally lean it forward to where the razor blades are directly on your skin and loose the height guide you've specified. So, if you have a nice thick beard you're trimming, suddenly you go around your jaw line and shave it down to a stubble. Now you have a big hole in your beard. It's terrible.<br /><br />I've wrote the same review on Philips' website, so hopefully this model is taken out of circulation. I did get another one from them and carefully examined how the trim guide was designed. Interestingly, all the rest have the guide (as I have traditionally seen) wrap around the razors so that this issue doesn't arise at any beard trim length you're going for.<br /><br />don't buy!
  1382. The blades stayed sharp and the battery life was excellent; but one too many times in the humid environ of my bathroom spelled the end for this trimmer.<br /><br />Shame, since otherwise it was rather excellent; though the vacuum feature was a bit gimmicky; I still ended up leaving stubble trimmings everywhere to clean up.
  1383. I've tried a few trimmers in my time, and this is by far the best one.<br />First off the one and two star reviews that mention the lack of the contour comb attachment are now invalid - it now includes it AND the new stubble attachment.<br /><br />1. Comes with both contour comb and stubble attachment. Use whichever one works better for you.<br />2. Works great for both hair and beard (I use the 4 mm setting for my head, can't say how good it is for long hair).<br />3. Vacuum system works very well and a real sink-cleaning time saver.<br />4. Small power adapter that works with 100-240 VAC, so can be used abroad.<br />5. No risk of trim height changing accidentally due to rotating ring selector.<br />6. Light weight, small size compared to a lot of wired trimmers.<br />7. Corded + cordless use.<br />8.   1401. This is a great beard trimmer. It is easily adjustable and easy to confirm/check the setting. It is lighter than my previous beard trimmer and has a great feel in your hand. The vacuum for whiskers works better than I thought making for easy cleanup. Would highly recommend.
  1402. Easy to hold, no cords to get in way. Efficient, effective, no nonsense trimmer. I bought this as well as the Pulsonic shaver system by Braun.   1403. This is not a BAD product at all. It works ok, but doesn't do exactly what I was expecting it would.<br /><br />I don't think the vacuum part is as useful as made out. I mean, it gets a majority of the hair, which is nice, but you still have to clean the sink. And for me, if I have to clean the whole sink/counter for some hair it wouldn't really matter cleaning it for all the hair. From some of the reviews I had expected the hair it missed sucking in to fall downwards , but instead (like just about every trimmer) it flings the little hairs everywhere. So the suction (even on high) doesn't cut down on the area of mess, just the amount of mess.<br /><br />The height adjustment is solid and won't be a problem / adjusting as you trim, but I still haven't been able to get it to \\"be a pro\\" at stubble. It works great with my mid length and shorter length beards. But for the \\"perpetual stubble\\" style, you'll need to look elsewhere.<br /><br />The mustache trimming is limited. It does trim my mustache (unlike some reviewers who said their nose gets in the way) but it just barely works. I still find it easier to trim the top of my mustache with scissors.<br /><br />The trimmer works fine, blades don't pull, build quality is great, weight is balanced, etc etc. Nothing is inherently wrong with the thing. It just promises a bit more than it can deliver. Unless you're keeping a simple mid-length beard, it isn't an all-around trimmer as advertised and you'll still need other tools to keep tidy.

  1412. Great trimmer and shaver.
  1413. I finally had to retire my old Norelco vacuum beard trimmer recently, as the metal grates over the vacuum intakes had gotten bent from knocking whiskers out of it, and the motor blades were grinding hard against the grates and making all kinds of noise. That and like others here, it wouldn't hold a charge and I had to have it plugged in to use it. I really liked that trimmer though and it served me well for years, so this was the replacement of choice. I was a hair concerned ordering this with the complaints about the comb, but when I received it I found that the box contained both the new comb everyone seems to hate, as well as the good trusty old contour comb. I went straight with the contour comb, so I can't say how the other one works, but it works like a charm with the contour comb and there is no nicking anything even on setting one. I would say it is even better than the old Norelco, as I sometimes would get a nick on setting one with the old trimmer, and I've not nicked anything on any setting with the new trimmer. They have made several improvements in this model over the old trimmer that I definitely appreciated. First off having a nice solid plastic body will be a plus, as there aren't the metal grates anymore to get bent and rub against the vacuum motor blades. Also the comb adjustment is stiffer and the comb doesn't accidentally change position during use like the old Norelco used to sometimes. I've also found that the battery holds a charge much longer than the old one, even when the old one was new. The vacuum is also more powerful and does a better job of pulling the hair into the catch chamber than the old trimmer. I loved the old Norelco but I would say this one is an improvement in every way. No complaints here at all! Nice Job to the Phillips/Norelco engineers this go around!
  1414. This trimmer works well with the contour following comb on a medium length beard. The vacuum feature catches most of the clippings. Holds enough charge to complete a beard trim. Charging time is per spec.
  1415. Latch that keeps the door on the hair compartment closed is very flimsy and broke very quickly. Now I have to hold it closed when I shave. Annoys me every time.
  1416. The unit came with two trimming heads. One is fixed and the other follows the contours of your face. I was surprised to receive both as I read a number of reviews before purchasing and many people complained that their unit only came with the fixed head and had to separately contact Philips to get the other head. The vacuum concept works better than expected. It does not pick up every last stubble but the bathroom is 99% cleaner! The only reason why I do not give the product 5 stars is that it does not give a close enough trimon its lowest setting (without the head piece). I need to use another shaver to reduce the stubble further (I am not referring to a close shave for which you obviously need to use something else).
  1417. Not happy with the price . Found the same thing cheaper in walgreens. Also there is one more version of the same brand does the same thing but not digital.

  1432. WORKS FINE AND INEXPENSIVE FOR WHAT YOU GET
  1433. I love the vacuum feature on this trimmer, however the door that holds the waste bin doesn't stay secured. Initially the door stayed shut, but about 6 months in the clasp no longer shuts. I now have to hold the door shut while trimming, sigh....
  1434. I got this for my husband. It's really nice because we don't get hair all over the bathroom sink since there is a vacuum inside it. Only con is that the storage space for the hairs is pretty small and you have to empty it pretty often.

  1437. I have used this trimmer for 3 months. The vacuum collection is surprisingly helpful. The noise level is certainly acceptable. This trimmer does all that's promised and I would recommend it highly.
  1438. A bit unwieldy for beard use. Otherwise quite nice

  1440. I had an earlier model and had problems with battery life (battery would not hold a charge) and warranty ran out so I decided they would have fixed the issue. I purchased this newer model and found out that I mis-calculated - they do not seem to have fixed the problem. After the order the one I received developed the same issue - after two or three months not holding charge. I sent back under warranty and received another, which developed the same problem after a couple of months. Again under warranty I sent in for a replacement to THAT replacement. Received that replacement (now third one of this &#34;new&#34; model) and after just two or three months THIS one no longer holds a charge. Philips' customer service is very good and they were responsive to my issue. I fully expected I was doing something wrong, but after careful discussion with them found I was doing what should have been done. Sorry, but after 4 units developed the same problem, I have to think this is not the trimmer for me. Hope none of you have this problem.
  1441. Good quality, provides great stubble look all the time. Do not use on your head.
  1442. Overall a decent replacement for my old Norelco trimmer (which broke when I dropped it in the sink. 7 years. Not bad). Needed to find a new trimmer that could produce a stubble beard. Searched far and wide and this particular trimmer appeared to garner recommendations towards that end.<br /><br />Things I liked:<br />* Locking wheel system for changing the guide depth. Much stronger than my old Norelco, which held on by a tiny clip<br />* Battery seems to last a good long time. I trim once a week and need to charge it every 1.5-2 months.<br />* The vacuum feature is new to me and I generally like it. It's not flawless, so I still have to cleanup.<br />* Found out that the best and fastest way to give me that stubble look is to remove the guide head entirely (0 mm) and use the cutting blades in a downward motion. Then cleanup with a 2 mm in various directions.<br /><br />Things I did not like:<br />* The brush for cleaning the collected hairs and such is small and easy to lose. I wish it snapped into place somewhere on the device.<br />* There is an additional gap/hole between the cutting head and the vacuum collection hole where lots of hair falls through to the grease-coated moving parts. From a design standpoint, I don't understand why this gap exist because the hair will stick around if you don't clean it. Recommend 1) pulling off the cutters and tapping out the hair after every trim and 2) more thorough cleaning of the motorized parts (with a rag or something) and adding fresh lithium grease every few months.<br />* It's rather large and it's less difficult to be precise, even when working with two hands<br />* Difficult to trim mustache because trimmer guide hits my nose. Needed to remove entirely and use 0 mm size.
  1443. Good quality product. I have no issues with it whatsoever. Been using it for a few weeks and it works very well. I recommend it to everybody.
  1444. To bad remington stopped making the vacuum trimmers , why'd they do that I have no idea, this norelco is one of the only vacuum trimmers left on the market but the blade is angled at a weird direction and the vacuum is right on top of the blade so you can't clean the blade easily after use. The door that the hair gets sucked into also feels weak and can probably easily be snapped off, dumb idea, why not put it on the bottom like remington USED to make instead of the top front. I use this to cut my hair with a buzz cut and it works great for that. I wish this had a base but it doesn't so you have to leave it on its side when not in use. It looks real cool though european styling on the trimmer, although nothing was as easy to use as the old remington mb 70 or mb 400 That stood up on its base. I'm glad to have this norelco cause vacuum trimmers are getting harder and harder to find these days. This has a kool blue digital light which tells you what mm the trimmer is on at the moment and also how full the battery is and when t charge it. So all in all its probably the best and maybe the only vacuum trimmer on the market, norelco also makes another vacuum trimmer but this is the higher model supposedly with much better battery life and much shorter charging time. So pick one up today.
  1445. Being able to assign numbers to trim levels can help you achieve the same look over and over. It takes the guess work out of the equation. The vacuum/container keeps the area clean from trimmed hair.<br /><br />I was originally looking at norelco's shaver line, but those are for clean shaves.   1478. I was looking for an electric razor that would allow me to trim facial hair short enough to be considered stubble and maintain it that way. The \\"stubble comb\\" that comes with the razor is crap. It's flimsy plastic and bends as you put this against your face, so whatever trim level you're trying to achieve is never accurate. You also end up scraping your face if you put it on the lower settings because it places the blade right against your skin. So...there's very little protection this device actually offers. There was another comb that came with the set that is supposed to be for longer hair (beards). It worked a little better in protecting my face because the space between the sides of the comb, in which the razor sits, was smaller so there was less of a chance your skin would get nicked. However, whenever I tried to maneuver around angles of any kind (jaw, chin, even around the lip) the gap between the comb would be enough for my skin to make contact with the razor and I'd get a very close shave. Wanted to return this and get my money back, but neither Amazon nor Philips make it easy to return this for a refund. Oh well, out $50. I ended up going with the Conaire iStubble and loved it. Much easier for maneuvering, better trimmer guard, cuts hair a lot shorter and truer to what I consider real stubble. Far superior device, so I say go for that one and skip the Philips Norelco.<br /><br />Update 2/14/14:<br /><br />The return process on this product is not easy. You can't return to Amazon because it's a personal care product. If you try and return it to Phillips using their \\"45-Day Money Back Guarantee\\" they will first make you wait 3 weeks \\"to make sure all your facial hair grows out\\" and you can fully test the trimmer. Then, I had to do two separate requests for the paperwork to send this back because the first time their customer service team totally forgot. They sent me the return paperwork on the LAST day of the refund deadline. I sent it in anyway, paid my own shipping costs, and haven't heard back from them. As if I need to repeat: do not buy this product.

  1515. I was going to get the Braun trimmer which got some rave reviews but then I realized the vacuum function from this is actually quite useful if you plan on trimming hair on your head which otherwise can get quite messy.<br /><br />If this is for beard, you can always use sink to catch the waste though if you're not careful, sink can get clogged quickly. I actually use the cheap Gillete trimmer/shaver for beard because that requires no charging and battery life is quite good. Of course, having a shaver head makes it easy to get nice lines.<br /><br />But back to this trimmer. It is very powerful. I just shaved my entire head last night with 2mm setting and 1mm on sides. Looks terrific. This takes practice by the way but since I was going for military look, it's a bit easier.<br /><br />The lines that I got from this is precise. I don't even need a razor to get rid of the small hairs. The angle of cutting is a bit tricky and requires practice. I was a bit worry for a while because nothing was being cut so then I just went from 18mm to 2mm setting and oh yeh, it works!<br /><br />There is a downside in that it takes an hour to get a full charge and also charge does not last long, less than the 50 min it claims. But trimmer works corded and cord is quite long so works for me.<br /><br />I basically never need to visit the barber shop again! The trick is to keep trimming now and then because when hair is longer it gets much harder and messier to trim as it was for me last night. No suction can suck hair that is too long, but trimming at short lengths, the vacuum works as expected and no mess at all which is really only reason that I go to barber shop - to avoid the cleaning. For now the military look works for me but I'm pretty sure depending on creativity and practice, I can create better and cooler cuts which my barber can never do because he's not me.

  1522. I purchased to replace a T980 I left in a hotel in Nashville... big mistake. The T980 was a great device and I had zero complaints. The OT4070 is decent and using the optional black trimming head attachment (included) achieves similar results. The stock grey head attachment that came in the original packaging is worthless. I think the majority of the \\"bad\\" reviews came from people trying the OT4070 with the grey attachment. The T980 cut more consistently but the OT4070 definitely does a more than adequate job. The only negative is the vacuum. The T980 vacuum worked perfectly... rarely leaving any shavings on the counter top. The OT4070 appears to leave about 30% shavings on the counter. Not bad but not very good. Otherwise the OT4070 serves its purpose. Norelco should reissue the T980 or make a better replacement.

  1534. I ordered the QT 4070 trimmer after having read reviews that it now comes with both blades and it is a great product. The product still works adequately, however I probably would not have spent as much money if I hadn't thought i'd get both blades. The one it comes with is uncomfortable. I called as recommended and after a relatively short wait and easy conversation was told the replacement blade would be in the mail and I would have it in 5-7 business days. It has now been three weeks. I called today and was told it is on back order. You'll get it when it comes in. I asked when it would come in and was informed that they have no idea. Perhaps this is a problem and so they are tired of these calls, but she didn't apologize or act like it was any inconvenience to me. In fact I was made to feel that I was an inconvenience to her.<br />It is still a decent razor. It shaves evenly although with discomfort mostly near the mouth region due to the blade. The vacuum is a cool idea and feature, however it only sucks up about 70% of the hair, saving you minimal time in cleanup. I will say it is better than not having it (but you pay for it). It is frustrating that many are receiving the product with both blades as I've seen photos on boxes and how I expected mine to come. Yet some of us are stuck calling and waiting...<br /><br />I will likely rate better once I receive and can use the missing the piece.
  1535. Likes:<br />1. You can plug it in if the battery runs out mid-trim and get the job finished, something that cannot be done with all brands of cordless trimmers.<br /><br />Dislikes:<br />1. The combs are very flexible, so if you press it against your face, the teeth will flex and you will end up with a much shorter beard that you had intended. To make it worse, parts of your beard will be shorter and parts longer if you don't apply exactly the same pressure against your face everywhere. I ended up with random divots in my beard after the first use. The solution is to always use a light touch, but really? The teeth could not be made out of firmer plastic, or shaped so they will not flex so easily? This is a ridiculous design flaw, in my opinion.<br />2. If you remove the comb for edging your beard or mustache, the vacuum intake blocks your view of the end of the blade (in the mirror), so there's no way to know where you are cutting.<br />3. On my beard, the vacuum is marginally effective, even at high setting. There's still a mess on the sink counter top when I'm done and then I have to clean out the vacuum too. It's a gimmick that just wastes battery charge time.
  1536. Bad trimmer just fancy case but does not improve performance in comparison with my 10 yr old norelco...very dissapoointed from this purchase
  1537. i opened it for the first time and found it doesn't work just after i flew back to China last month.
  1538. I've had this for about 5 months.<br /><br />My girlfriend likes me scruffy. I couldn't care less, so I wanted a fool-proof easy solution. It's rechargeable, super simple to use and never pulls or snags on my beard. The vacuum feature is helpful and catches almost all the clippings, but I still stand in my dry shower and use it before I turn on the water so I don't get bits of hair everywhere. This is NOT waterproof.<br /><br />No complaints!<br /><br />I don't think you're supposed to keep it plugged in, so sometimes I reach for it and it needs a charge. In about 5-10 minutes, I have enough juice for one thorough trimming.

  1565. Battery lasts a long time and charges fast. The vacuum feature prevents hair from getting everywhere. It adjusts to the millimeter.<br /><br />Great choice.
  1566. This trimmer performs as expected. The vacuum built in is handy in keeping MOST of the fine stubble from getting on the counter. My only two problems are this: One: The size is somewhat large for a beard trimmer. This makes it difficult for getting places like just under the nose. Not impossibly, but difficult. This isn't a deal breaker. Two: The first one I received had a weird issue related to power. It would work perfectly for about 2 or 3 trims (5 minutes or less each time). On the next one, it wouldn't even power on. It was as if the battery had drained 100% even though the prior use showed 100% power remaining. I did an exchange though Amazon and the new one has worked perfectly. I've charged it once and have used it 5 or 6 times and has 3 of 4 battery indicator bars remaining. Update after 2 Years: I've had this unit now for almost 2 years. It trims well and the guard(s) have help up very well. I still enjoy the ability to adjust easily and that function still works great. The big issue with this unit, for me, is the battery. I still have weird battery issues with it. One example is this past weekend (Christmas 2015) and traveling. I had about 75% battery left and I decided to let it charge overnight to make sure it would last the 5 days I'd be on the road. Well, I packed it but ended up not using it (hello Christmas beard). When I got home, I went to shave and the unit said the battery was dead. This is the problem I've always had: something is either draining the battery or the electronics controlling it are messed up. Also, recently, the plastic door over the vacuum compartment has failed. The little clip has simply worn off so now I have to hold it closed with a rubber band. I enjoy the ease of use with this trimmer, but the weird battery issues make it impossible to travel without packing the charger.
  1567. Light weight. Easy to use. Great range of settings. Replaced older Norelco when I needed sharper blades and the catcher cup broke.

  1569. Honestly speaking I was afraid to buy this trimmer after reading all the confusing reviews, but then I've decided to go for it and give it a try.<br /><br />I have a beard trimmer from braun that lasted for longer than I can remember, but the battery is dead and I was looking for more precise trimming settings, so I thought it's time for a change. I took my trimmer out of the box (which btw comes with the contour following comb as well), plugged it in to charge while I read the user manual, and took it for a nice smooth drive.... The results?<br /><br />Vacum:<br />It sucked 85% or even more. I wasn't even interested in such feature, but using it I have to say that I am impressed... Please keep in mind that this vacum is put into such small size - you are not carrying the carpet hover in your hands :)<br /><br />Trimmer<br />This thing gives you perfectly EVEN trim everywhere... this was a big issue for me with my old trimmer, and I am more than pleased with this trim... smooth, nice, and even :)<br /><br />Contour Following Comb<br />This is a great addition to your trimmer. I have used it around tricky places such as my neck, and it serves you good... you might need to choose a different trimming length than with the normal comb, especially if you hold your trimmer in a more angled way like I do.<br /><br />Trim Length Settings<br />18 trimming settings that I think are fabulous, you can choose from 1, 2, 3, 4, 5..., 18 mm with 1mm difference between each setting... Preferably start with long length for the first use and go down step by step - they tell you to do so in the user manual but I was stupid to think it's the same settings as my old trimmer, so I ended with shorter beard than usual.<br /><br />Cons: No Pouch?<br />My only concern is the fact that it doesn't come with a pouch?! seriously philips, charge me an additional 10$ for a decent quality pouch and I would be more than happy to pay for it... fortunately for me, it fits perfectly in my Braun pouch :)<br /><br />Long story short... For the first time in my life, I had my beard professionally trimmed at the comfort of my house.<br /><br />Buy it without any hesitation ;)
  1570. This piece of crap was a waste of my money. If it gets wet, the trimming length displays the incorrect values.   1571. This was getting bashed with 1-star reviews because they weren't shipping the contour comb.<br /><br />Now it comes with it, so no complaints. I doubt you actually need the turbo-boost, so it might be better to save and get the qt4050.<br /><br />I chose this because it says it can shave to half a millimeter, where the qt4050 can only go down to 1mm.<br /><br />Some people are complaining it can't catch their beard hairs. I'm like ... seriously? You think that trap was going to catch shavings over a quarter of an inch long? The instruction book does explain if you want the vacuum to work you might have to go in two passes, so the shavings are small enough.<br /><br />I use this frequently, so have short trimmings. It catches almost all of my trimmings. The trimmings that wind up in my sink are from cleaning them out of the vacuum section.<br /><br />I will say it is virtually impossible to cut yourself with it. There is a bigger gap at the sides of the bare guard. I have a couple times managed to smash part of my lip into there, but it just stung for a split second, no bleeding. So, you may want to be a little careful around your lips if you don't have a comb on it. Normal skin tissue cannot fit into that gap.<br /><br />One minor complaint: It can't charge quite as fast as it spends battery power. Meaning, it will have to be plugged in for a little longer than it takes you to shave to stay at full battery. It usually barely doesn't get charged all the way from the time it takes me to trim, then clean it.<br /><br />NOTE: It's a Lithium-Ion battery, so you should keep it charged full at all times to preserve the battery life.

  1579. I've owned many trimmers, razors, and shavers and this one seems to be the best one out there. As you've probably noticed by going through the reviews, the old reviews about the comb stabbing you is no longer an issue because they also provide the contour comb as well.<br /><br />At first when I started using it, I didn't really like it. It seemed as though I had to do more work than I bargained for to get a nice even shave. I played around with the different settings and adjusted the length multiple times only to see that there were still a few rogue strands sticking out. However, after just setting it to the length I hoped would be correct, I just pushed in through the hair to the skin and let it fly and that seemed to do the trick. It seems with this trimmer that being afraid to make some minor mistake is not the way to go if you expect to have a nice even shave, and no you do not have to apply pressure, just let it trim the full length of hair up to your skin. So, with that being said, I will explain the pros and the cons:<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Easily switching trimming lengths<br />I have a goatee and a full beard so I tend to trim them both down to different sizes, so switching easily to different lengths was a big deal for me. This shaver does that with no problem, simply slide the adjuster and keep shaving.<br />- Turbo mode<br />I guess this is a pro, as the few times that I have used it I haven't really noticed a huge improvement in the speed and efficiency of shaving seeing as the regular mode does the job just fine in a timely manor.<br />- Battery life<br />I charged it once I received it to full battery and haven't charged it since and have been using it almost on a daily basis. (Have owned it for almost two months.)<br />- Vacuum<br />The vacuum is new to me. In general it's great because before I had to deal with cleaning up a lot of hair in the sink and now the cleaning is very minimal. Depending on your beard size and how much you trim, you may have to do multiple empties of the hair trap.<br />- Precision<br />This is a major pro for me. If you use it correctly and know the right length to trim everything down to then this trimmer can be very accurate at giving you an even shave.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Vacuum<br />The hole where the vaccum sucks in the air is somewhat small and can get clogged easily. If you're letting your goatee/beard grow out and trim down a decent amount then expect to make many trips to clear out the hair trap and unclog the hole.<br />- Sans Beard<br />Obviously this is a trimmer and you can't expect to be able to get a full clean shave out of it, but it gets it down to a fairly minimal amount of stubble to be able to easily shave it with a companion device. In hindsight, maybe I didn't work at it enough to get a full clean shave as most of my shaves are early in the morning when i'm rushing out the door.<br /><br />All in all, this is a great trimmer and I would recommend it to anyone who has a beard or goatee. It may take some getting used to until you get that perfect shave down, but once you do you'll understand what you need to adjust for the future shaves.
  1580. Piece of junk. The vacuum design is a joke. clogs with hair in the first few seconds of use. I find I have to take it apart and clean 4 to 5 times every use. What a waste of money
