  1611. This thing is great. I've noticed people complain about &#34;cutting their lip&#34; I am truly baffled by this. Even with the &#34;stubble&#34; guard, which in all fairness *does* look intimidating when all the way down, I still was unable to cut my lip or cut myself in any way. You would literally have to be &#34;duck facing&#34; while placing the trimmer vertically directly onto your lip. If you are doing this, put your trimmers (and certainly any razor you might own) away and lock them up.<br /><br />The &#34;stubble guard&#34; (gray) will give a scruffy look, which I personally prefer, and the contour comb guard will give a cleaner feel when grooming your face fur. The vacuum does an okay job but some facial/body hair will still escape and have to be cleaned up. Short of affixing a shop vac to your trimmers you will be hard pressed to find a pair that captures every shaved hair. These trimmers are great they charge super quick and last for a considerable amount of time on a single charge.<br /><br />I've used a lot of trimmers and these really are one of my favorites!
  1612. It is good for alot of facial hair and you can trim your hair as you like it. Love it!!
  1613. Contrary to other reviews, my 4070 came with the contour comb, which is very similar to the one that the T980 used. Other than a smaller chamber for hair that requires emptying far more frequently, I am very pleased. This device is doing the trick.<br /><br />I was hesitant as some of the reviews I read were pretty polarizing, but I have not been disappointed. I keep pretty short hair on my head and during work travels I even use this to give me a quick buzz if I feel like my hair is getting too long and it has worked well.<br /><br />I keep my beard a bit longer than the hair on my head and the QT4070 allows me to quickly trim my my beard. My only complaint which existed on the T980 is that I have a hard time trimming right under my nose, I have to remove the guard and carefully trim my moustache area right under my nose, but I've gotten pretty good at it.<br /><br />If you like the T980, this will be a change, but I don't think it will be as drastic as some reviewers have painted it, as long as you have the right guard, because the alternate guard is horrible.

  1616. I picked this up when my husband asked for a beard/mustache trimmer for his birthday. He's always so worried about making a mess in the bathroom, so I thought this vacuum shaver would be a great idea. However, if you don't shave everyday, the hairs start getting too heavy to be vacuumed properly, causing the vacuum feature to not be as awesome. Every day is just more than my husband is going to do, so I wish the vacuum was a little stronger. Other than that, the trimmer seems to work fine and my husband has not complained.
  1617. Storage chamber for the hair is very small, other thatn that it is good to use and compact to store for travel purposes.
  1618. Really like this product- I thought the vacuum was not going to work very but it works amazingly well. I used to go outside to trim my beard with the other trimmer I had [was just a hair trimmer], thought I would have to do the same with this one to keep from trying to clean up a bazillion little hairs in my bathroom sink, but the vacuum works very well and cleanup is very easy and quick at my sink, as it gets most of the hairs, but not every single one, Also like the adjustment for length, it is very precise.
  1619. I already own some older Norelco trimmers and they work great. I bought this trimmer specifically for the vacuum feature because cleaning the since up every time I trim is annoying. When I trim the clippings are always less than a quarter inch, so long hairs do not explain why two thirds of the trimmed beard still ended up in the counter. Don't know if this was a defective trimmer but it did capture about a third of the mess. That's not enough to make it worth the money though. I sent it back.
  1620. Cordless which is great. Haven't had to charge it yet so holds charge and stream line shape is very comfortable to use.
  1621. I find the product very good. I like the battery life indicator, the digital settings, etc. It does a good job of trimming and the built in vacuum is easy to dump. The only thing I dislike is that it indicated free shipping, but when I used the $5 discount coupon I got charged $6.95 for shipping. Not much of a discount coupon.
  1622. I bought both this and the other &#34;vacuum&#34; based shaver from Remington to test them side by side, and the Phillips wins by a mile. Great readout of how long you have the clipper set to, the construction just feels sturdier than the Remington, it's now in daily use for me.
  1623. Pros: It does what it's supposed to do; it did arrive with the second (\\"Contour\\") trim head; the trimming blades are wide<br /><br />Cons: Too many parts with flimsy construction; needs a small moustache comb; you are limited by few other similar products<br /><br />It appears from many, many previous reviews that this trimmer had arrived with only \\"Stubble\\" trimmer\\", and not the \\"Contour\\" trimmer. As is the case with several more recent reviews, my trimmer was thankfully packaged with both (in fact, this was the first thing that I checked).<br /><br />I like the Norelco QT4070. I got a good trim the first time I used it, as I was able to apply techniques learned from 10 years experience with the Wahl Trim-n-Vac (the only other trimmer I've ever used). The Norelco arrived with the \\"Stubble\\" trimmer already attached. I don't use this trimmer since I can't figure out how it's supposed to work. It has a large gap in the combs across the front of the trimmer blades, which just looks like a disaster waiting to happen. I immediately removed it and attached the \\"Contour\\" head, which is what I always use now.<br /><br />The instructions state that you should use a moustache comb (or any fine-toothed comb) in preparation before using the trimmer, very good advice which I certainly always follow. It's just that the trimmer doesn't come with one. For the 50 bucks people pay for this thing, one might think Norelco could throw a small moustache comb into the box (fortunately, I retained the one that did come with the Wahl Trim-n-Vac).<br /><br />One very nice feature is that it can work with the cord - you don't NEED to charge it. It also does a very good job of vacuuming beard trimmings. But one must remember: it will NOT catch every shard of trimmed hair - NO vacuum trimmer out there will! You WILL still have to clean up afterwards. Another nice feature is the wide trimming blades, which measure at least 1-1/4 inches. The Wahl was only 1\\" wide.<br /><br />The problems I have are with flimsy parts. First, as many reviewers have pointed out, the door holding the beard trimmings is very cheaply constructed. Both the hinge and the small tab which keeps the door closed seem about to break at any moment. A better design would be like the Wahl Trim-n-Vac, which used a removable cup to capture trimmings. No small pieces, no moving parts, no chance of failure.<br /><br />Secondly, as many, MANY other reviewers have stated, the trim head combs are flexible and not rigid. This means that someone can easily compress the comb, resulting in a trim SHORTER than that set on the unit! Therefore, you MUST remember to be careful and NOT push too hard as you shave.<br /><br />Third, the \\"Contour\\" head has a weird, overly-complicated design. It has a flat top which is a separate piece that pivots on a spring-loaded hinge. This is supposed to move in order to stay in contact with your skin as you move the trimmer around your face, chin and jaw. As with the other parts I've mentioned, the spring feels very weak and seems prone to break. A far better design would have been a trim head NOT with a flat, movable top, but with a single-piece, CURVED top, negating the need for moving parts to maintain contact...again, JUST LIKE the Wahl Trim-n-Vac. I suggest Googling it for pics to see what I mean.<br /><br />Overall, I am satisfied with the Norelco QT4070. It does what it's supposed to do, which is provide an even trim for my beard. It does vacuum much of the trimmings. It has wide trim blades. It can be used with or without the cord. But I have many concerns regarding parts that are at the same time cheap & over-engineered. And Norelco really should provide the 15 Cent moustache comb its own instructions recommend people use with this product. Lastly, anyone looking for a vacuum beard trimmer will be hard-pressed for other options, as there just aren't that many vacuum trimmers out there. After doing a lot of web-research, I figuredI'd take a chance with this one. So far, it does well, but I do hope this trimmer lasts even a fraction of the 10 years my Wahl Trim-n-Vac lasted.
  1624. This was given to my 37yo son for Christmas and he loves it. I have had one for about 10 years and love it, too.
  1625. My old Norelco T765 stopped charging, so I bought this new model. The T765 was much better at cutting and it was much easier to pop the guard off. Also, the Money-Back Guarantee from Philips is complicated that requires you to chat or call them and then work through a series of emails. You also cover the cost of shipping it insured back to them.<br /><br />Update: Philips has not responded since Monday thus dishonoring their money-back guarantee. The great thing about Amazon is that they're taking it back for free.
  1626. I also was a huge fan of the older T980, which finally gave out on me after many years of reliable shaving and trimming. Without this, I find that I have to hold the trimmer at a very awkward angle to shave/trim my sideburns and other area. Previously, the sliding piece would adjust to the angle of my skin and allow for a clean shave. This model does not do that and I am struggling to find the best angle to obtain a clean shave. I would not recommend this unit and am disappointed with Philips.

  1633. So let me preface this by saying I'm a big Norelco fan. I have a 12+ year old norelco shaver (from my pre-beard years) that I still use occasionally and a 5+ year old norelco beard trimmer that's still going strong.<br />as this beard trimmer was meant to replace the existing basic beard trimmer I already have, I'll compare this new model to it. note that unit is very basic and probably cost $15 new.<br /><br />Pros:<br />I like the battery indicator, so I can easily see if I have enough batter for the next use.<br />After a 20+ minute marathon trimming where I slowly stepped down the length setting, the battery indicator barely seemed to go down.<br />the trim length dial was convenient and easy to use, and having the digital length value was a plus, but this was only mildly better than the manual adjustment I have on my existing trimmer.<br />while I know some people said their battery stopped holding a charge, I of course didn't have time to test this in a short time, but the idea of having a lithion ion battery and not having to worry about leaving it on the charger between uses is a definite plus.<br /><br />Cons:<br />The vacuum, and this sadly is a big one, as it was really the only reason I wanted to replace my existing working unit. with this new one. It's pretty much a long affair in the shower with my current trimmer, as my stubble just goes everywhere and normally covers the entire bathroom. so it's messy and requires a shower right after. while the vacuum on this new trimmer works, in both turbo and non-turbo mode, as someone else mentioned in their review it only really sucks up about 50% of the hair. there was still way too much stubble all over the sink. a little i could handle, but 50% ( and I think that's a generous number), it's just not worth the premium for this trimmer over the basic one I have. not sure if it's due to my bristle beard type or what, but it just didn't work well enough.<br />The new trimmer is about 1&#34; longer than my existing unit, and definitely thicker. I guess that's needed for the vacuum, and could be overlooked if the vacuum worked better.<br />My existing trimmer came with a simple stand and several additional attachments, like a nose hair trimmer. sure I've not used it, but it's nice to know it's there in case of a freak nose hair attack. the new unit came with none of this, so was a little disappointing.<br />it's louder than my existing unit. not terrible, and like the size thing, could be overlooked if the vacuum worked better.<br /><br />Sadly, without the vacuum working better, it was just not worth keeping and had to go back. as mentioned earlier, I'm still a big fan of Norelco, but this one was just a little disappointing.

  1673. I've been using this product for several months now so I guess I can make an objective review on it:<br /><br />First off, I love this trimmer, but it's not without its flaws. I have a messy beard so I like to trim it without paying too much attention to detail. Overall, I like the messy look of a short trimmed beard and the QT4070 nails it on this regard. It is, however, a nightmare for those who are looking for a product capable of doing intricate beard designs and so on. This is a kind of messy look / on the go product. Oftentimes you'll want to finish the trimming with a simple razor, maybe to get some hairs on the cheek.<br /><br />Design is hit and miss. Philips didn't use to provide the QT4070 with the contour-following comb, but this is no longer a problem, so kudos for them. This comb feels very comfortable on your face and it is the only one you'll ever need (the other one is garbage), but you'll need to remove it later on if you want to get to those hard to reach places, like under your nose. I found myself using the comb on the lowest millimeter setting and finishing my entire beard after removing it just to be safe. It is, again, not a very precise product, but this method works fine for me.<br /><br />Regarding the vaccuum system, It does its job capturing about 90% of the hair inside the handle. But the little plastic \\"door\\" which houses the captured hair is very cheap and it'll become loose overtime.<br /><br />Pretty much everything else works as expected. I love the battery life and the fact that it is maintenance free.<br /><br />If you're looking for a trimmer that will leave you with that messy 3 o'clock look, this is the product for you. However, for anything more than that, it is pretty much worthless. Luckily it is just what I was looking for.

  1679. After reading all the negative reviews here on Amazon for this Phillips 4070 (cut lip after cut lip!), I was hesitant...? A tad on the cheap plastic-ee side (but what isn't nowadays), but unit and parts are tight when assembled gently and work very well for an under $50 clipper. The digital display for the length selected and the current charge leaves no doubt about current status. I have been wanting a razor for a shorter stubble beard, but since I am light BLOND, it needs to be a little longer to give the same effect many guys with darker hair can have with even a single day's shadow. I need around 4mm, and this 4070 make this a breeze to keep my blond shadow beard at the current perfect length (and if I get fickle and want it longer, a few clicks of a dial and I am there, and with digital length confirmation to boot!)<br /><br />The vacuum feature works great, and keeps things nice and neat. The cut hair storage compartment opens easily, making throwing out the hair a breeze (though the enclosed brush or a Q-tip make it much easier and thorough). Taking the clipper apart to clean the cutting mechanism is also very easy to do (not so with many other under $100 clippers!)<br /><br />Many of the negative gripes were about the stubble comb, but I have used both the stubble and the curving comb, and both work fine, though I prefer the stubble comb with my shorter beard. I don't think I could cut my lip if I tried...!

  1685. To start off, I HATE trimming my beard. Clean up is the reason that I hate trimming my beard. The trimmings are always too much to simply wash down the sink. When a friend told me that he has a vacuum trimmer that actually works, I was intrigued. When I searched online and saw the relatively low price, I was ready to purchase!<br /><br />Some older reviews say that you get one trimmer guard that pokes and causes un-even trimming, but rest assured, that is not the case any longer. There are two guards, and I personally use the spring loaded one.<br /><br />About me:<br />- I do have a full beard 365 days a year, so I trim my beard often.<br />- I trim my beard 1-2 times a week.<br />- I have a coarse beard<br />- I use guard setting 3, which is fairly short.<br />- I am not sure how it works on hair other than facial hair<br /><br />Comfort:<br />- I find that the trim is comfortable<br />- There is no hair pulling like some other trimmers that I have used<br /><br />Trim:<br />- I have professional hair clippers that I used to use, and I feel that they did a better job, but that is an unfair comparison<br />- The trim head is wide enough that trims do not take a super long time<br />- I have noticed that I have to make 2-3 passes around my jaw line. I hope this will get better as I learn to use it differently<br /><br />Clean up (the best part):<br />- If you expect to not have to clean up any hair, this is not the product for you<br />- The vacuum picks up between 80-90 percent of my weekly trims, which is impressive<br />- Clean up has now been reduced to simply washing the missed trimmings down the sink, and dumping the trimming compartment<br />- The trimming compartment fills up with one shave, so some people may need to empty the compartment more than once in a shave<br />- I do not use the turbo mode, which could catch more hair, I am not sure<br />- The cleaning brush that is included is one of the best ones that I have used. There is a firm side and a lessfirm side.<br /><br />Charging:<br />- I have shaved 8 times so far, and it still has over half of a charge<br />- If you travel outside the US often, you shouldn't have to worry about charging this unless you are gone for more than 2 months or trim more than 1-2 times a week. (but you probably have a converter anyway ;-)<br /><br />Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who needs to trim hair often.
  1686. The popular Philips Norelco did not even last a year. Constantly charging it before every use. would not recommend it.
  1687. first off the trimmer does a good job and the vacuum feature is pretty cool. it doesn't catch every single hair so you'll still have some hairs in the sink/on the counter but it is significantly less than the all the other trimmers that don't have this feature.<br /><br />as far as the actual trimming, while it does an overall good job, I found it difficult to get to the moustache hairs under my nose and the beard hairs close to my ears. I'm not a hairy sasquatch you understand, but rather the trimmer head is a bit bulky and I found not as effective in reaching & trimming these 'nook & cranny' type areas of my face. I ended up trading it in for this one which while lacking the vacuum feature I have found more adept at getting to these hard to reach areas. http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00ARF44O6/ref=nosim/6688506-rg1112-0020-20?s=merchant
  1688. I love this beard trimmer - cordless, charges quickly, and even has an electronic lock for traveling so you don't *need* to bring your charger. This was the SAME design complaint I had on my previous one from 8 years ago. Sad to see Norelco hasn't changed the design, otherwise it's a great trimmer.

  1696. [[VIDEOID:mo230YS073I4DNL]]The Norelco Beard Trimmer provides men the ability to maintain clean facial hair whether it's a stubble, goatee, or full beard. The precision of the trimmer is incredible. The trimmer has settings that allow you to trim from 1mm up to 18mm. Changing is as simple as rotating the controls.<br /><br />The trimmer also has a vacuum which eliminates the mess created from trimming. It has a convenient slot to empty out the trimmed hair. The trimmer includes a lithium ion battery which means you can charger it via an outlet and it will hold that charge for quite a while during cordless use.<br /><br />The Norelco Beard Trimmer retails at 49.99 and provides an efficient and fast trim. If you maintain a beard or stubble, you need to trim it everyday and the norelco is the perfect tool for the job. Overall the trimmer is constructed really well and feels efficient to use. Don't waste your time with poorly designed trimmers, the norelco is your best choice. View the full video review here: http://bit.ly/AmazonNorelcoReview

  1699. Used the Philips Norelco T980 Beard Trimmer w/ Vacuum for years and loved it. Used it to trim my beard and, since I like a stubble cut on my noggin', I used it to mow my head. Didn't take real good care of it, so after a few years the door to the clippings holder broke and the battery degraded to where it need to be charged prior to every use.. Bought the QT4070 thinking it was just an updated version of the T980.<br /><br />IT IS NOT.<br /><br />Still cuts pretty good but the suction on the vacuum is far, FAR inferior. This model clogs every, single time I use it, I have to continually tap the clippings down into the compartment, and clippings still get everywhere. I have a pretty tough beard and the vacuum is not strong enough to keep the hair from flying everywhere when cutting my beard. It's almost unusable on my melon, because when I turn it upside down to do the top of my head, the suction is barely enough to keep any stubble in the catch compartment and it clogs almost instantly. The T980 never did this. I've run the 2 units side by side, both fully charged, and suction difference of the vacuums can be clearly heard. Oh, and the new design on the door on the 4070 is lousy too, it quit staying closed the 1st month I owned it, had to put a rubber band on it to keep it closed.<br /><br />This thing has a lot of good reviews, I just wonder if anyone giving it 5 stars has ever used the older model. They don't know what they missed.<br /><br />Just recently, did a patch job on the old T980 catch compartment (duct tape and a big rubber band) door and have resigned myself to charging every time before use. I've kept the 4070 as a back up...

  1744. This is my second Norelco beard trimmer. The first one I had a few years ago, and it became faulty within around 2 months of usage. It was still usable, but the hair collector door had broken with normal use, the vacuum was completely gone, and it would keep jamming up no matter how carefully I cleaned it. I put up with it for a couple of years, thinking that maybe I'd just gotten a bad one or that I had mistreated it somehow (can't think how).<br /><br />So recently I saw this \\"updated\\" model on sale and figured that maybe they'd improved the design, or that I'd just make doubly sure to treat this one with kid gloves. Well, a couple of months later and I'm back in the same boat.<br /><br />Listen to the other reviews where they say this scrapes and nicks your skin - it does. The edges are sharp and it's not a smooth, comfortable experience at all. So right away, it's actually WORSE than the previous model. But that's not all. Already, it's developed the same problems as my old one:<br /><br />* The door to the hair collector refuses to click shut. On the old model, it was completely removable, except the fastening tabs were so fragile they broke within weeks. On this model, they've added a hinged door, but the fastener no longer works. I have to keep it closed with my thumb while using the device.<br /><br />* The vacuum stopped working very quickly. It works a little, but after shaving my sink is literally covered in hair. The vacuum is so weak it might as well not be there.<br /><br />* The \\"turbo\\" setting constantly jams. It will work for about 3 seconds and then stop, showing an \\"Error\\" message on the LCD display. I regularly clean the thing of hair with the brush, so I just don't see how you stop this happening with normal use. I'm reduced to using it on the oh-so-slow \\"normal\\" setting and it takes forever.<br /><br />I'm really annoyed that I threw away more good money on this piece of junk. The worst part of it is that many retailers are dominated by Norelcowhen it comes to shaving and beard trimming products, so there isn't a lot of choice. I will however be looking around for a quality beard trimmer from now on. Don't listen to the good reviews written here - I suspect that many of them are based upon the reviewers' initial thoughts, and not based upon their long term experience with the device.

  1757. I read a lot of reviews discussing the type of clipper guard this came with, so I was pleased when I got mine and it had two kinds of clipper guards. One is the stabby kind like people mentioned, but it does a good job getting closer. I use it for that close stubble trim. The other is spring loaded and works contours of your face better. I use that one for beard trimming.<br /><br />The vacuum is nice. I've never used an electric trimmer before, so while I know how messy they can be, I haven't experience it. This vacuum will by no means catch everything, and you'll still end up wiping down the counter when you're done, but it seems to catch the majority of falling whiskers. I don't ever use turbo because I just don't consider my facial hair to be thick enough to be worthy of it, but I may try using it more in the future for the vacuum boost.<br /><br />The battery lasts so long that it's hard for me to actually say exactly how long it lasts. A month or two of 3-4 uses a week pretty easily I'd say. If you're the kind of person that needs trimming daily, I'd expect you could still get a month or at least a few weeks out of each charge, and the charging is fast when it is needed.
  1758. It got the job done for about 6 months. But the product ultimately failed due to a seemingly mal-engineered weak spot.   1772. I am mystified at the many 5 star review this item has received.<br /><br />The QT4070 Beard Trimmer has an incredibly stupid design. Whoever came up with it should be fired. The problem is with the placement of the vacuum air intake. They placed it in front of the cutting head. This means that the cutting head is set back from the front of the contour comb with the result that you cannot cut within 3/8-1/2&#34; from any object that restricts the forward motion of the trimmer...like your nose. Result? You can't trim the top of your mustache!<br /><br />Other flaws:<br />-- the vacuum attachment is loud.<br />-- poor comb design. It has a sharply angled leading edge which is uncomfortable as you run the trimmer over your face<br />-- limited functionality, Again, due to the placement of the vacuum intake, you can't take off the contour comb and use the trimmer to, er, trim sideburns, etc.<br />-- ergonomics. The vacuum feature bulks up the overall size of the trimmer. I find it significantly harder to maneuver this unit than other s I've used.<br />-- expense. This is one of the more expensive trimmers out there.<br /><br />NOT recommended.

  1782. This is my fourth Norelco beard trimmer (can't replace the batteries economically in Norelco trimmers) and it is simply adequate. For many reasons I preferred the \\"dead\\" one it replaces. For example, the last one had a little sliding \\"basket\\" to catch the vacuumed clippings and thus I could slide it out and tap it on the sink to empty it. This one has a non-removable catch area with a depression behind a \\"difficult\\" door and must be cleaned with a brush each time. Why did the designers think that would be viewed as a blessing by guys in a hurry? Also, the last one was smoother in operation and never \\"snagged\\" whiskers as this one sometimes does. It is noisier than any of my previous Norelco trimmers too. On the plus(?) side it uses lithium batteries so it goes full power until it stops unlike Nicad batteries which warn you by slowing down a little one or two shaves before stopping. I hope this never stops dead when I am running late for an important appointment. The regular speed and vacuum power is really more than enough, so I am wondering why they gave it a \\"turbo boost\\" setting. I tested it out of curiosity and my ears actually hurt when I shaved near them. I can't imagine turning on turbo it in real life use.<br />Update of 4/23/13<br />I recently tried to see if the two \\"blade heads\\" on my last Norelco fit this razor and they did. Using the old blades improved the experience significantly and one of the blades was a special blade for close fine trimming which was not part of this new razor. While I am now happier I am not changing the rating since the improvements didn't ship as part of this razor package. The point is to recommend you see if any earlier Norelco blades you may have on an old razor will fit on this one.<br />Update of 11/11/13<br />The \\"difficult door\\" retaining the clippings (mentioned above) no longer works since the catch no longer holds it closed. A little plastic nub disappeared and now it requires a rubber band around it tokeep clippings from being blown around the room...they need to rethink designs.
  1783. Have used the trimmer for a while now. I like that it holds a charge for a l long time. The vacuum feature is neat and works pretty well. I don't like that it's a little harder to do precision trimming because of the thickness of the end. That's not a big issue. It still works for me. I would recommend.
  1784. I purchased this because I had a stubble trimmer from Norelco and I absolutely loved it, the problem with my old one was that it didn't hold a charge after a few months of usage, and now it doesn't even work well if its plugged in. So I purchased this product, and even at the lowest setting it doesn't have the same control as the previous trimmer I was using. This is the old one for reference:<br />http://www.amazon.com/Philips-Norelco-QT4021-Stubble-Trimmer/dp/B0039UM90C/ref=sr_1_29?ie=UTF8&qid=1361831500&sr=8-29&keywords=norelco+beard+trimmer<br /><br />If it held a proper charge I would give the old one a 6 star rating, it was absolutely amazing. p.s. I didn't pay 100 for it, I'm assuming they upped the price because norelco discontinued it or something.

  1787. Product works as described by others. As others have said the vacuum system isn't perfect but better than nothing. The latest iteration which has a part number QT4070/41 comes with both head attachments... the one which people originally complained about as beling sharp our pointy is not very good at the longer trim lengths because it could be pokey... and because it's too flexible so it's not very consistent due to the tines flexibility, but if you want the shortest possible stubble you need to use that attachment so i think it's worth having if it's super short stubble that you're after... (which is probably why they included it in the first place. I want slightly longer stuble so i use the &#34;softer&#34; less pointy head which is better suited to the long lengths as well.<br /><br />Last but not least a REALLY cool feature of this trimmer is it's travel worthiness becuase it isn't just that it'll trim while it charges, but it'll run on any voltage just like pretty much all cell phone and laptop power supplies. The reason i ended up on the market for shaver was becuase i blew up my last shaver in europe plugging it into an average 220V socket with a plug adapter. It obviously runs on the USA 120V, and you can run it on 220V in europe (with just a basic plug adapter) so you can plug it into anything without owrries... and don't have to use any fancy power voltage converters to use this anywhere.

  1793. I was using a Phillips Norelco beard trimmer, and really liked it. So immediately bought this model as it looks similar to my older model, with the exception of the display. I'm a bit unhappy after receiving this model. With the comb removed, it doesn't seem to trim close enough, so you can define the line between beard and face. The biggest issue, is that this model only has a screen at the bottom of the compartment, so it quickly clogs of beard trimmings, and no longer vacuums them. The older unit had a little basket that pulled out, which also had screens on the side of the basket, keeping the airflow going, so it would vaccuum effectively until full. They appear to have cost reduced the feature to the point where it no longer really works. Too much hassle to return. Will look elsewhere when the battery on this one finally dies.
  1794. Like many I got this as a replacement to the T980 model which I had for years. They are basically they same, although I got more with my T980 which I also paid less for.<br /><br />The main missing element is the detail blade. The T980 came with two blades, a wide blade that was used with the contour comb and was good for trimming your beard. And a narrower blade, which was used without a guide to detail the edge of your moustache or beard etc. I used both every time I trimmed my beard.<br /><br />The new model, only comes with the wide blade, no narrower detailing blade. To me this is is a massive draw back.<br /><br />The only other missing element is the travel pouch which was nice to have.<br /><br />Regarding the vacuum system, it never really worked well with my T980 and it seems to work no better with this model. Sink clean up is still very much required. So if thats your motivating factor for purchasing this model, I would think again.<br /><br />I do like that this model is apparently less prone to turning on unintentionally in travel - I haven't road tested this claim out yet, but that was an issue with the T980.<br /><br />Overall I think they could have done better improving what I think is a good product but this will do.
  1795. Previous reviewers have stated the same in regards to how the beard guard does not really work due to it not covering the top of the unit completely. They have also stated that you can buy a replacement guard that should resolve the problem. I have not done this but, it is an inferior model compared to the Philips Norelco® T980 Turbo Vacuum Trimmer. I had this model and it felt like a better built unit in every aspect. Skip this one, and if you can find one, get it the T980 over this one.

  1797. This trimmer was really sharp right after I had purchased it. It already came with the special guide mentioned by some other reviewers. However, after about 8 or 9 months, the vacuum feature started missing some. Eventually it got to the point where it hardly sucked up any hair at all. After approximately 24 months of use, I have decided to retire it and purchase something else. I was looking for a well-rounded trimmer, one that I could use without hassle. This one was not it.<br /><br />(1) The vacuum feature eventually &#34;clogged&#34; up.<br />(2) I had to go over my face, A LOT, to get all the straggling hairs.<br />(3) A single charge might keep for a while but it only lasts me for one, maybe two trims of my beard. It worked better when I only had a goatee.<br /><br />If you only plan to use this for a year, it's fine. If you're looking for something to last until the cows come home, keep looking.
  1798. This is an outstanding product, better than any other vacuum clipper on the market.
  1799. I'm not sure how other guys have been stabbing themselves with this trimmer; I had no such trouble. I got the best, fastest, neatest trim I've ever given myself in 20 years of having a beard. The only complaint I had was that when I tried it corded the cord dropped out. Otherwise, perfect! Even the trouble areas of my face where my hair seems to grow in all directions wasn't a problem. I had to attack from each different direction but once or twice each way was enough. I've never been able to trim that area so easily. The vacuum is awesome as well. No, it doesn't get every whisker but it was so much better than no vacuum and worked at least as well as is reasonable to expect. The only thing I can't speak to is durability, specifically battery life. Obviously, hoping that satisfies as well. Update: I've been using this trimmer for almost three years now. I'm still happy with it and the battery is holding up well! That's a vast improvement from the horrible battery life of my last trimmer, an Andis.
  1800. UPDATE: The comb is flexible so dont push it against your skin \\"to make sure you get an even trim\\" because it ill just cut it shorter than desired. I didnt get cut but if i was carelless with it, it might happen.<br /><br />It good all my hairs even, except in the mustache area which it left them a little longer, but withing acceptable and understandable limits.

  1808. I bought this trimmer over a year ago and am very happy with it. I use it on a full beard, the contour comb set to 3 mm. It is as sharp as it was when I bought it, and the contour comb is easy to set and gives a consistent cut. The comb pulls off to trim your mustache or hairline without changing your setting. The vacuum does prevent a mess in the sink and surrounding counter. The trimmer is easy to clean with the included brush. I was initially put off by the fact that it does not come with a charging stand, but I quickly found out that it does not need one. The charging cycle is so long (use = 2-3 x per week), that I don’t know how many MONTHS it goes between charges. So the charging stand stays in a drawer not taking up counter space or drawing a phantom current. I have charged this thing only a few times since I bought it well over a year ago! It is a well designed trimmer.
  1809. I purchased the Norelco QT4070 in February 2014 as a replacement for a failing Norelco QT4022, which was purchased in 2011. Shaving closely with a razor or electric shaver causes my skin to break out. I primarily use the QT4070 to maintain a 1 mm &#34;designer stubble&#34; look.The vacuum feature is more than just a gimmick. Although it doesn't totally eliminate hair in your sink when shaving, it does dramatically reduce the amount. The battery lasts for over a month at a rate of 3 full face shaves per week. The unit charges quickly and has a useful digital battery indicator. The large plastic guard does make it challenging to trim directly under your nose and line up my sideburns, but it is doable by using the unit and specific angles. The one downside I found is that after about 4 months of use, the plastic vacuum container door latch broke. I contacted Philips and they replaced the unit. I am happy with the product and manufacturer's policies regarding their product. I'm confident that you will be happy with this product should you choose to purchase it.

Another observation is that my moustache is harder to trim than my beard even though it is not thicker than the latter, perhaps it is related to the nature of my own anatomy than to this product in order to give the benefit of the doubt to the latter.   1860. I purchased this trimmer to replace a Norelco I bought in... wait for it... 1999. It lasted so long because I replaced the internal NiCad battery 2-3 times. I've retired it only because it needs another battery and I'm sure the clipper's blades are worn out.<br /><br />Based on this experience and ratings here on Amazon.com, I selected this product. I'm a little disappointed.<br /><br />+ Incredibly long-lasting Lithium battery has meant I've needed to charge it only after a whole month of use<br />+ Vacuum feature captures about 95% of cut hair, keeping my bathroom counter and sink area cleaning<br />+ Sharp blades make it unnecessary to cut again and again to catch long hairs<br />+ Digital length indicator makes it easy to set and verify length, even without my reading glasses<br /><br />- I found this to be a very disappointing choice for detail work. It is designed such that the vacuum's &#34;scoop&#34; prevents seeing the cutter when you are using it without the &#34;comb&#34;. This means I cannot see what I'm doing when I trim my sideburns or mustache to length, which is frustrating. I did not have this problem with my old Norelco.<br />- The two &#34;combs&#34; are harder to reinstall then the old Norelco. It usually take 2-3 attempts to get everything aligned so the comb can slide down.<br />- Norelco also changed the design of the cutter head such that the head itself must be completely removed for cleaning. This also creates a reinstall issue. My old Norelco had the head attached with a hinge, which made it easy to clean but also completely removable if needed.<br /><br />For the way I use a trimmer, I would not purchase this model again. The obstructive view is the deal breaker.
  1861. So far works very well and trimming is very easy.
  1862. Its a really good trimmer, but like many other wrote the door to the vaccum chamber broke after a few months so that feature is gone. Shame really. Also it is hard to trim the mustache area because of the inset way the trimmer is set up.
  1863. Excellent product. Bought to replace an earlier model in which the rechargeable battery died. This one is working well so far.
  1864. This product looks great, works great, and the vacuum feature is a fantastic feature. It's not perfect, meaning you will still launch little hairs in every which direction, but it does capture the vast majority of your shavings.<br /><br />When I bought this product, it came with two guards - the stubble and the contour. Be warned - ALWAYS USE A GUARD. If you try to use this to trim your pubic region, you will probably cut yourself if you don't use the guard because the blades are VERY sharp. I learned this the hard way. Always thoroughly clean the device if you use it on more than one location on your body.
  1865. The variable trim settings are great--just take some experimenting to get the right length/look. The vacuum doesn't seem to catch too much--still end up with hairs all over the sink.
  1866. When my trusty and much beloved Philips T980 recently gave up the ghost, I was a bit worried about replacing it with the new QT4070 due in large part to some of the adverse reviews I'd seen on Amazon. But, when it came to a vacuum beard trimmer, the QT4070 is just about the only bar in town so I got one. I was very pleasantly surprised at what the device turned out to be... it's essentially the old T980 in a new shape with an upgraded Li-ion battery and some fancy new display technology. All the things that I loved about the T980 were still there in the QT unit. In fact the cutting mechanism is essentially identical so I was actually able to use the T980's mustache trimmer on the QT4070 (the parts were interchangeable). As far as the QT's being a replacement for my poor departed T980... it was an exact match. In fact the only down side is that the new trimmer does not come with a narrow mustache blade and it also arrived sans case. However, as I said before, the T980's trimmer works just fine on the QT and, of course, the QT fits in the T980's case. Punch line: If you're looking to replace a T980 don't hesitate to buy the QT4070. For all intents and purposes they're the same unit.
  1867. Vacuum works great. Combs need some redesign so that they will do a better job of lifting hair and guiding it into the cutter. As it is, there are quite a few long hairs that it misses.
  1868. Bought this as a replacement for a Norelco T980. Very pleased with this trimmer as it is very similar to the T980. Vacuum works well.
  1869. Somewhat inconsistent cuttingâ€”I find beard hairs not cut and just kind of bent. The vacuum feature reduces the mess, but there are still clippings that escape. Overall, worth it despite shortcomings.
  1870. I've had this shaver for about a month now and it'd like to cut straight to the small things that have stuck out to me rather than do a full review Pros -Charged it once since the day I got it and it's still carrying a a 4 out of 4 bar charge now a month later -Came with the interchangeable form following head -Only extra pieces are the other head it came with, a cleaning brush, and the A/C adaptor which is great compared to my old multipiece trimmer. Cons -The vacuum to pick up hair isn't the greatest and sometimes the area that sucks hair in will get clogged, but it's an easy fix. Even with the vacuum not being the best I still give this five stars because it simply makes beard trimming a snap and it has great battery life which used to annoy me with my old cadmium powered shaver. Pick this trimmer up if you're in the market. You won't regret the decision.
  1871. vacuums up the mess as you trim. can't ask for more than that! second time I have bought this one and it does not disappoint.
  1872. Good quality product. It arrives at described.
  1873. As my older Norelco T980 finally started to show its wear after its remarkably long life, I decided to upgrade to its replacement top-of-the-line trimmer. After studying many wildly-mixed reviews, I had some concerns with the newer razor. However, considering how happy I had been with the performance of the T980, and my intended use of the trimmer for achieving stubble, I dismissed the negative reviews about trimming longer hair and purchased the trimmer anyway. Initial impressions were very good.<br /><br />The QT4070 looks very sleek. It feels much ligher than the T980 while offering a seemingly larger hair chamber and the LCD display, which deserves its obligatory mention. It's ability to use both corded and cordless is also an excellent feature; my battery arrived drained, but plugging it in allowed immediate use. It also does away with the spring-loaded vacuum \\"chute\\" that forever frustrated my use of the T980; it replaces it instead with a solid-plastic chute that extends all the way to the clippers. Unfortunately, my excitement was curtailed when repeated uses of the trimmer all left hair covering the counter top. I'm not sure if the defectiveness is due to this change, or a new, weaker vacuum.<br /><br />My trimmer arrived with both of the described heads - a fixed \\"stubble\\" head, and a spring-loaded \\"comb\\" similar to the T980. The stubble head differs from the comb in two main ways: it has no spring-loaded tail; instead resembling a single, flat, solid unit atop the trimmer; and it has the \\"guard\\" teeth in front of the razors removed. The latter point seems to be a huge design flaw, leaving the razors entirely exposed and ultimately shearing skin twice in the first use before I resigned to using the \\"comb\\" head. The comb head, while much safer, also seems to perform poorly. Both the comb and the guard teeth seem much flimsier than the older T980, allowing the distance between the skin and the razors to vary depending on the pressure applied. This seems likeanother major design flaw, as it's extremely difficult to hold the razor at the same angle, with the same pressure all over the face. The result is needing to re-trim areas of my face several times in a futile attempt to achieve consistency before ultimately accepting the uneven trim.<br /><br />I'm left with the impression that the QT4070 is trying really, really hard to distinguish itself from the older T980. While the trimmer makes several significant steps forward in design; it falters on functionality, offering inferior performance with its vacuum and dangerous or uneven trims with the stubble and comb heads. If these issues were resolved, the trimmer would easily warrant a 5-star review. Unfortunately, in its current incarnation, I must reluctantly retire its use and return to my worn-out T980.
  1874. I returned this product after trying it for a week because the vacuum is kinda gimmicky. I don't have very thick beard hair and it just didn't do a good job of sucking up the hair...I imagine it would be even worse for someone who produces a 5'oclock shadow. That aside the product was sturdy and came with a travel bag which is a plus.
  1875. Had to replace my Phillips Norelco Vacuum trimmer that was about four plus years old, and falling apart. This new one is so much better. It works fast, feels good in my hand, and trims just as I want. My beard is slightly longer than Wolf Blitzer on CNN. I use the rigid guide, and set the trimmer at 6mm, for a perfect beard. I remove the guide to trim my mustache, which I like natural length, just trimmed above my mouth, unlike Wolf, who looks like he runs the trimmer flat over his mustache. The trimmer is easy to clean, and tells you how much charge is left. The old one simply slowed down, when it needed a recharge, and then it took ten hours to recharge. This one charges in an hour
  1876. Decent enough trimmer, but after 6 weeks of ownership, it no longer holds a charge.<br />After fully charging the unit, it's good for no more than 3 trims - that's less than 10 minutes of actual usage.<br />I informed Norelco customer service of the issue.<br />That was a positive experience since they made a no-hassle warranty replacement of the unit.
  1877. I've had a beard for a long time and I generally get a new trimmer every 3 years. At least, that's been the average life of the trimmers I've had. I bought this Phillips Vacuum trimmer after reading reviews online and determining which would suit me best. My previous trimmer was a Wahl Lithium battery unit, which I was quite fond of but bit the dust after 3 years. Most of my comparison will be to the Wahl.<br /><br />The Good.<br /><br />The thing I like best about this Phillips trimmers is its design and ergonomics. It has the same tactile rubbery plastic that my Phillips Sonicare toothbrush has, though with a black face for masculinity. It fits well in my hand and feels substantial and well made.<br /><br />I also really like the adjustable length guide and the digital display. My biggest downside with my previous trimmer was that I had over a dozen attachments to keep track of. Also unlike my old razor, this Phillips does not require oil. It trims my beard very well and its easy to dial in the perfect length. Previously, Id trim on the short side and let it grow in. Not so with this trimmer.<br /><br />The big selling point of this trimmer is obviously the vacuum. It does work very well. I'd say it traps about 70% of the trimmings and the rest land in the sink. You would need to empty the chamber multiple times if you're doing serious trimming duty, as it is pretty small. The vacuum is ideal for the lady friend because girls hate hair in the sink. At least that's been my experience.<br /><br />The Bad.<br /><br />My most prominent difficulty with this trimmer is that it is quite imprecise for edging. Because the vacuum surrounds the blades, it's difficult to see where you're going. I'm getting used to it, but my previous trimmer was much better.<br /><br />The trimmer also lacks power compared to my previous one. I always use 'turbo mode' because regular just doesn't have the speed and vacuum power that is necessary.<br /><br />In addition to edging difficultiesand lack of power, the blades are much larger than previous trimmers I've had. This means that its difficult to get close on cheeks and for neck shaving. It gets it down to a fine stubble, but for a smooth neck you'll need an additional razor. Luckily, stubble is in fashion. So, i just let it be.<br /><br />Finally, the battery is good for about two weeks with daily use. My Wahl went about 6 months on its first charge and it was much more powerful. The Phillips redeems itself by having the fastest charging time I've seen with a digital display of battery life. I charge it with a similar cycle to my Sonicare. The downside of the low life is that I have bring the charger with me if I travel, and a travel case was not included.<br /><br />The Verdict.<br /><br />Overall, I love this trimmer. If they can address the issues I pointed out, it'll be perfect. It's great for beard trimming but bad for edging and neck shaving. I'm getting used to it and can tolerate its shortcomings because it does everything else so well.
  1878. THIS IS MY FIRST USE OF A BEARD TRIMMER .I CHOSE THIS MODEL AFTER REVIEWING NUMEROUS BEARD TRIMMERS OFFERED THROUGH AMAZON .THE EASE OF A SINGLE, MULTIPLE LENGTH SETTING , WITHOUT HAVING TO ATTACH VARIOUS COMBS , AND THE VACUUM SYSTEM SOLD ME. NO LUBRICATION/MAINTENANCE WAS THE OTHER SELLING POINT. I BOUGHT THE TRIMMER VIA AMAZON AND IT CAME 2 DAYS EARLY ON STANDARD SHIPPING . BUT THE REAL TEST WAS HOW IT WORKED .IT TRIMMED MY HALF INCH BEARD DOWN TO 1/8TH INCH - WHICH I SET IT TO -IN LESS THAN 3 MINUTES. NO PULLING EVEN GOING IN DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS ,A VERY PRECISE AN COMFORTABLE TRIM WITH NO MESS. A SUPERB PRODUCT! JIM G.
  1879. I got this product after trying its lesser model, the QT4050. I was not impressed with the weak vacuum in the QT4050, and promptly returned it. After looking through the reviews, I decided to get the QT4070 to give it one last shot before I gave up and stuck with my trusty Wahl.<br /><br />I'm happy I gave it a shot.<br /><br />The vacuum on this model appears to be more powerful, picking up all my shorter hairs, and only having a bit of trouble with longer hairs. I found when I tried to go fast over longer areas I lost a lot of hair to the floor. A fix for this was to simply go slow when long hairs were concerned.<br /><br />A big plus for this model is the removable guard. I have ridiculously sensitive skin. Sensitive enough that I tear with even the gentlest of razors, so I'm forced to rely on trimmers such as this one for day to day shaving. The static guard on the QT4050 meant I could never get anywhere near a close trim with it, always leaving me with a decent amount of stubble. The QT4070 allows me to remove the guard entirely, leaving me with as close a trim as possible. (I did not check if this was possible on the QT4050, so I may be wrong)<br /><br />This isn't on the description, but I did get the \\"contour\\" guard alongside the non-contour guard. For those of you that keep a beard, it'll be nice to have. Unfortunately, I do not know if it is just a fluke that it was included with mine, so be ready to take a gamble on it if you need it. That being said, I expect the pro model to have everything the standard model has, and then some.<br /><br />Edit: After reading through the reviews, I came across this review that mentions the status of the contour comb guard thingy http://www.amazon.com/review/RYVNB0DI05PLJ/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B003U8ESI4&linkCode=&nodeID=&tag=<br /><br />I read some negative reviews about the hair bay. To be honest, I don't see the issue. The bay is easily accessed, if not slightly difficult to open without fingernails. I consider that to be a positive thing though, as an easy open hatch would be prone to opening by mistake. My advice if you're worried is to open it over the trash barrel. You're going there anyways, might as well be diligent.<br /><br />The only issue I have with it is the lack of any type of stand or case. When traveling, I don't like leaving things like this loose. I'll just get a cheap split leather pouch for it, but I really shouldn't have to. As for the stand, It's not a big deal, but I still shouldn't have to do without.

  1920. My T980 has finally bit the dust after many years of reliable servers - the battery wouldn't hold charge, and even running plugged in would barely crank the motor. So I ordered this as a replacement.<br /><br />The good news:<br />- contour following comb was included in the box.<br /><br />The bad news:<br />- everything else.<br /><br />- vacuum performs much worse than T980 - I have to clean up far more after even a casual trim.   1922. I bought this to replace my Philips Norelco G390 beard & mustache trimmer which I've had over 4 years so there were no doubts in my mind that Philips Norelco was a good brand to go with especially the QT4070. Despite the 1-3 star reviews I went ahead and bought the machine and it seems that Philips Norelco has decided to ship the beard guide which comes with the QT4050 model as an additional attachment apart from the one that comes as a standard with the QT4070 model. I guess they read the 1-3 star reviews and found that a majority of them expressed dissatisfaction with the beard guide and the effect of the trimmer blades, which are indeed over exposed on the beard guide, cutting lips or stabbing faces so they decided to include the additional comb/guide.<br /><br />Apart from this the trimmer is well made and the designed thought out with a stylish touch to it with the LCD which indicates the battery level and trimmer size setting once adjusted. If you are an avid eletric beard trimmer user then you would see that the guiding comb (both of them) comes in handy and can be used over several application. I like the fact that the trimmer takes a minimum of an hour to charge for full use and they (Philips Norelco) experimented with a vacuum to catch the hair in a compartment which could work as an advantage (for users with short beards) or disadvantage (for users with long beards). Maybe next time they can just eliminate the vacuum compartment...since not all of the hair will get caught...and use the space for a bigger lithium-ion battery so that would add to customer advantage of longer batter life (just a personal suggestion).<br /><br />But the product does stand out for me and gives me one of the closest shaves I've had and this is solely gauging from my previous PN product and based on this I would recommend this to person's looking for a trimmer that doesn't break the bank and offers a quality shave.

  1926. I like this product because it's compact and easy to use. For people like me whose facial hair tends to grown in one direction, the flat blade (as opposed to the circular types) makes it easier to get my hair length to what I want it to be. People have said the product is noisy but I don't feel that way. If you put it in Turbo mode, then it's a bit noisy but not so much. The positive attributes are the comb, which directs the hair in a particular way if you wish to have a longer length; and the adjustable hair lengths is the other positive attribute. The best part is the vacuum feature where I have not had to clean up a single mess. Plus, the product comes with a tiny brush to clean up the hair.
  1927. I found the product to be unsatisfactory in many ways and sent it back for a refund after a couple of trials. The three biggest problems were that the trimmer pulled, rather than trimming, my hairs. It was very uncomfortable to use and, because of the pulling, did not result in an even trim. Second, the vacuum feature did not work to pull the trimmed hairs into the device; instead, it seemed to scatter the hairs all over the sink and the surrounding area to a much greater extent than my previous trimmer, that did not have a built-in vacuum. Lastly, while the unit claimed to be able to hold an extra-long charge, in the two instances that I used it, the charge was completely gone after single and relatively brief beard trimmings.<br />For what it's worth, I replaced this product with the Norelco Multigroom 3100, which I have found to be completely satisfactory. It does not have a vacuum, but it does not broadcast the hairs during trimming. It also does not pull my hair and has a charge that lasts.<br />I have been a loyal Norelco user and was glad to be able to replace the inadequate trimmer with one which measures up to the quality I expect from the company.
  1928. The best trimmer I've ever used. The little Norelco beard trimmers keep getting better & better!
  1929. Excellent product! After many different purchases that were not satisfactory, this razor hits the spot. My husband finds it delivers everything it promised.
  1930. Loved it initially. It was exactly what I was looking for, sleek, easy to read number system. Even came with a blade guard attachment that you could use for your more sensitive bits. Then the problems started. First it was the LED number system no longer read the correct height. I would just stay on three no matter the height. I could have lived with that since I'm not an idiot and can figure out which one it's on. But the real kicker was when the battery died. The unit just started blinking orangish unless it's plugged in then it works. This was after 3 or 4 uses. So much for cordless.<br /><br />Honestly I was a little sad that this happened. I had high hopes for this unit, but in the end I'm just returning it.
  1931. Trimmer works great. It's a good replacement for my old Norelco T-770 that is dying a slow death. My QT4070 came in a different color than pictured-red trim-, but that wasn't a big deal to me. Mine also came with the Contour Comb. Some reviewers complain that it was missing in theirs.
  1932. I love the precision of this trimmer. If you hit your lip with it your are not doing it right. I did hit my lip, but it didn't hurt. The vacuum feature works great. I would like to see the nose and ear trimmer like this.
  1933. When I first got this it worked very well for about 3 months then it broke.
  1934. My husband bought this, said to be very good and easy to clean
  1935. I recently decided to grow facial hair and I bought this trimmer based on reviews I read. I don't have experiences with other trimmers, but I can say I am perfectly happy with this trimmer. I have had it for a couple months now and I do not have any complaints. It does a nice job trimming and I haven't had any issues with it &#34;pulling&#34; my hair instead of cutting it. The trimmer is very simple to adjust for the length you desire and cleaning is a breeze. The battery seems to last quite a while as well. I can go through an entire week of trimming (ever other day) without having to worry about plugging in the trimmer. Also, if you travel a lot, this trimmer has the ability to lock the power button so it isn't accidently turned on in your travel bag.<br /><br />As a note, I maintain short facial hair (3-5mm range). I haven't tried these trimmers with longer facial hair.
  1936. Great job keeping those peaky whiskers in control. Works great on my husbands very thick roughage.
  1937. This is a very nice trimmer. While better than my previous, the vacuum catches about 85% of the trimmings (even on the turbo setting) so it is not perfect. It has great battery life and a powerful motor so it doesn't pull whiskers. The power adapter is rated from 110 to 240v so it works for overseas travel. (Worked for me Shanghai. Most outlets in China have the universal adapter face built-in already.)<br /><br />My one & ONLY gripe: this thing REALLY needs a travel pouch!!!!!!<br /><br />The price/features ratio made this one the best choice for me. So yes, if I lost it or left it in a hotel room, I would buy another just like it.
  1938. Vacuum system work very poor. It wont be wrong to say that it doesn't work at all. Battery life is just 30 mins as opposed to 50 state din the item description. extremely dissappojnted
  1939. Great beard trimmer. I thought that the contour trimming comb works pretty well. It does help giving an even stubble beard. The vacuum does work, somewhat (you can expect a few pieces to fall off from the trimmer).<br /><br />I had a few concerns though with the vacuum design: the vacuum container seems a bit too small (fills up quickly with the trimmed hair). The door to remove the accumulated hair is a little fragile (could easily break). The blades were on the same height as the vacuum entrance. So, if you are trying to give a close trim without the comb, you might need to use a different shaver/trimmer.
  1940. I like it, works so good & it work wile charging.
  1941. great all around ,no complaints
  1942. I received my new trimmer last week and I couldn't wait to try it.<br /><br />I used it for the first time to shave my thick beard and it worked fine, just as expected.<br />It is really easy to be used and so smooth, you will certainly love it.<br /><br />I recommend it for you guys !<br />I have attached a picture of the trimmer that I have received.<br /><br />Note:The color that I have received is black and white, I was expecting to get the other color shown on the first picture but this issue is not a big deal.
  1943. HE loves it as much as I do..... not as much mess and easy to empty and clean! Cuts great! The battery doesn't last long but otherwise its awesome!
  1944. Works great! Ordered another one...
  1945. I previously had a Philips Norelco beard trimmer that was pretty good. Finally decided to replace it when it was about 5 years old, because it wasn't holding a charge. This one's 6 months old. The catch that holds the door closed on the collection compartment is broken and the trimmer doesn't hold a charge for more than 2 uses.
  1946. This was purchased in an attempt to stop the &#34;you left hair all over our sink&#34; arguments with my wife. It has certainly helped. I keep my beard short, nearly stubble, and this trimmer works quick and with no pull. I do wish the vacuum was a bit stronger but honestly, I have nothing to compare it to and it DOES catch a good portion of the hair. This thing also holds a charge. I mean it HOLDS a charge. I use it 2 - 3 times a week and I've charged it maybe 3 times in a little over 2 months. The digital display is a nice touch and clearly tells you what setting it's on and how much charge you have left.
  1947. I bought this trimmer as a replacement for the earlier model (given to me as a gift). I really like how it trims my beard, the vacuum feature, and its ability to hold a charge. The vacuum feature makes a big difference in terms of cleaning up the sink and counter after shaving.<br /><br />I purchased this newer model because the beard trimmings door latch broke. I can still use the old one by using masking tape to replace the latch, but this makes cleanup a lot more trouble (beard trimmings stick to the tape too). I'd traveled a bit with the older trimmer, so I figured that it must've reacted poorly to packing.<br /><br />The new model arrived. More power, better vacuum feature, ability to use it plugged in if battery is low (older model didn't allow that). Nice! Really nice to have the trimmings door latch working again... but not for long!!<br /><br />After only 7 - 8 months of weekly use and used only at home (so it wasn't banged up in luggage), guess what stopped working? Yup, the trimmings door latch. REALLY? I babied this trimmer, and it just stopped latching again. Wow... back to the tape trick (escaping from that was my main motivation behind ordering this newer model).<br /><br />That just sucks.
  1948. Sent it back.<br />Not able to do closer trimming and in smaller areas.
  1949. Works great to clean up my beard when I let it get too long.
  1950. Have used several times and found this product has good battery life. The digital cutting length is a very nice feature. Seems to have more suction than previous models. The door for chamber seems more substantial than prior model. Very pleased with trimmer.
  1951. Pros - holds a charge and charges fast, neat display, vac actually works, you can use it plugged in<br /><br />Cons - I use it on my neck and cheeks with a full beard. It doesn't cut as close as my old Panasonic did. It also doesn't cut as long. The door that collects the clippings broke after a couple weeks and doesn't click closed anymore.
  1952. Received in good order. Works great.
  1953. This is intended to not be comprehensive, a lot of folks have done an awesome job with the pros and cons, I don't see a need to rehash all that information. I have used Norelco trimmers for ages and have loved some and hated some, but I always expected two basic things. The ability to set a height for beard/mustache/eyebrow/whatever trimming and then the ability to take the comb off and trim up close and personal. This trimmer delivers famously on the first one. Unfortunately, the nature of the vacuum intake makes the second one impossible. Once you pop off the comb, you just can't get close enough to do that fine tuning you would expect from a trimmer.
  1954. Does the job, I wish it had more power
  1955. Excellent Product as advertised.
  1956. Does part of the job, but could work better... still lots of hair on the sink.
  1957. used for about one year and love it. trims easily and evenly.
  1958. works great, the vacuum system is a must have.
  1959. Purchased to replace an earlier model where the battery burned out. This new model has a better design, is more comfortable, comes with two heads to guide the trimming process. The trimmer has more minute legnths for trimming. It is quite, accurate and does the job. It can be switched off so the trimmer does not start buzzing in your luggage when travelling. There were a few mixed reviews on this model but I took the risk based on my prior model. I couldn't be more impressed with its design and how well it works.
  1960. This thing works great. Catches probably around 90% of the hair. I can see why some people have had problems with the shavings door, but as long as you're mindful of that when opening it you shouldn't break it.
  1961. Works as described, haven't had any issues with it. Works great! would but again.
  1962. The trimmer works great in allowing me to grow a standard beard/mustache that will go well with my nazi youth haircut and black V neck sweater accented by a plaid collared checkered shirt as I sip on and pretend to know all there is to know about coffee and/or craft beer while discussing the unfairness imposed on poor people.
  1963. This thing is awesome! It allows me to maintain permastubble.
  1964. Easily the best trimmer I've ever owned. Pay attention to more recent reviews, the unit now comes with two different guides. Still a little hair to rinse away, but it catches the vast majority of trimmings.

  1966. The main reasons for my purchase was the vacuum system that captures hair inside the trimmer handle as you cut. The door broke after less than 2-months... hair all over the place. I now have a rubber band around it, which can cause the adjustment to move. It is either a poor design or a cheap plastic part. Before this problem I was ready to purchase one for a friend.
  1967. Just dont ever rinse the head off. Took me a while to realize that you could disassemble it to clean it out. :P

  1972. I love the trimmer itself, it is really great. Yeah, some of the hair still falls, what can you do. Cleanup takes a bit of time as well. But for what it is designed to do I think it is really good. BUT - I am on my 3rd unit after only 5 months!<br /><br />The first unit broke when the latch to the little door broke off. It renders the entire unit useless because the door is integral and cannot be replaced, nor is it easy or convenient to use it with the door opening while you shave - it makes a mess. So, after some trouble with customer service (they wanted to send me the QT4050 as a replacement - why would I want a cheaper unit?) I got a replacement. Things were going well until one morning - NADA. the unit wouldn't turn on, power, charge or function in any way. Customer service was better this time - sending me a new unit no problem.<br /><br />We will see how this one does, but my expectations are low at this point. So just make sure you register it because you may be talking to customer service a lot!<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />NOW ON MY 6th UNIT! The door latch only seems to last about 5-6 months no matter how gentle you treat it. I lowered my rating to 2 stars as I cannot recommend a product that breaks this often.
  1973. Vacuum isn't as strong as I had hoped, but it provides a great shave and I love the digital display.
  1974. ETA. The replacement unit had the same problem as the original, the latch failed after 20 or so uses. I am using a rubber band now to keep the hatch closed, as I frankly don't have the time to go through the return process again. Other than that, it is a great trimmer. Now updated down to three star.<br /><br />This is a great trimmer for the &#34;5 o'clock&#34; look. The vacuum system works really well, very few whiskers in the sink. *however*, as other have stated, the latch on the unit to release the cut whiskers does break. First time, Philips replaced it for me, no problems asked (hence 4 star review). In fact, Philips support was probably the best I have ever experienced. When a gold box sale came up for another, I picked up another one.,spare. I think I could use a rubber band to secure the hatch, if the latch breaks. This thing works too well, so I give the latch a break.
  1975. Does a great job trimming. Seen other comments suggesting that it cuts an uneven length due to hinged comb-head not following facial contours. Well I have not found this at all. I have used both the hinged and fixed comb-heads and find both work perfectly. I prefer the fixed head because I find it easier to manipulate but not by much.<br /><br />Only down side is that it is not as good at catching all the cuts hairs as perhaps I would like. But it does a pretty good job. You just have to keep emptying the little catcher, and expect to do a tiny bit of clean-up when you have finished. But it is much better than just dropping cut hairs everywhere.<br /><br />All-in-all I would highly recommend this unit for keeping a beard smartly trimmed.
  1976. One of the best around according to my husband.
  1977. Good function and easy to use. Appears to also hold the charge well.
  1978. I originally got this because I had a nice beard going... now I just use safety razor to shave. As for this product? Yeah, I use to trim my ball hair.
  1979. I had one of the older styles of Norelco trimmers that I wore out.<br />I bought this one and it works so much better, the turbo vac<br />system is great. I use this both on my head and beard.
  1980. this product is recommended to me and it performs exactly is it was supposed to. Very easy to use and maintain.
  1981. I purchased this product to replace the older version of the same product. My man and I love this trimmer and recommend it highly!
  1982. Works great for me. I've had it a couple weeks trims as well as i would want a trimmer to!
  1983. This is a great trimmer/vac, but is missing some of the things that would make it an outstanding one.<br /><br />Firstly, the good bits. It cuts hair easily and effectively unlike some that make the right noises, but no noticeable difference to your beard. The vacuum is, I would guess, about 90% effective at capturing the hair, and the attachments are both easy to use.<br /><br />Now the not so good. The battery life is not as good as my Norelco shaver. After a week of light use (4 times for about 2 mins each time), I set the travel lock and made a trip to New York State. When I broke it out to use it there it was dead... My shaver went strong for the next two weeks of daily use! I know it's new and I should have charged it again, but come on...<br /><br />The other bug bear is that it doesn't come with a travel case (unlike a Norelco shaver). A small detail I know, but that would make this $50 shaver great value.
  1984. Job well done<br />Trimming is great and fast. the vacuum is not 100% accurate but like 95% .<br />the colors are very bad black vs white vs ...<br />the design is very great (easy to handle and light).<br />But between this and the new generation philips 5100 ( I tried both of them) the last is easier to handle and to use. also it has a precision trimmer which is great. but it's slower than this 1 in trimming (no turbo). so if you don't want the vacuum go with 5100 or 9100.
  1985. I had been through a few of these trying to replace an old Remington. I finally tried this one and it's been great for over 2 years. Seldom needs charging, gets through my beard with ease. Very pleased.
  1986. Got this based on the reviews and am very pleased. As other reviewers have pointed out the contour head works best and I guess Norelco heard the complaints and now supply both. It's a very nice product my only suggestion for improvement would be to make it quieter.
  1987. I like the fact that it has a vacuum but the thing is it doesn't really vacuum all<br />of the trimmed hair. As a trimmer alone it is well worth the price. The vacuum also<br />works, just not perfect.

  1990. I've owned my norelco beard trimmer for almost 14 years and loved it. The trimmer finally started to wear out, so it was time to shop for a new one. I did my homework on the new model norelco, but had concerns over some reviews I read concerning the<br />adjustable blade guard being sharp edged and nicking users. I will tell you this problem was more the fixed. It trims better than my old one and is faster as well. I highly recommend this trimmer. I also include a fresh bottle of Wahl clipper oil which is a must to maintain your trimmer.
  1991. Difficult to use without the guard as the vacuum part of it gets in the way. Meh
  1992. This trimmer is awesome but has one major flaw...It doesn't come with a smaller detailing blade for the stash.
  1993. Very good quality build. I did break the latch for the hair storage area door, but have been able to keep using by holding it shut while in use.
